     170              : // SSL implementation.
     171              : 
     172              : 
     173              : // SSL contexts.
     174              : //
     175              : // |SSL_CTX| objects manage shared state and configuration between multiple TLS
     176              : // or DTLS connections. Whether the connections are TLS or DTLS is selected by
     177              : // an |SSL_METHOD| on creation.
     178              : //
     179              : // |SSL_CTX| are reference-counted and may be shared by connections across
     180              : // multiple threads. Once shared, functions which change the |SSL_CTX|'s
     181              : // configuration may not be used.
     182              : 
     183              : // TLS_method is the |SSL_METHOD| used for TLS connections.
     184              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *TLS_method(void);
     185              : 
     186              : // DTLS_method is the |SSL_METHOD| used for DTLS connections.
     187              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *DTLS_method(void);
     188              : 
     189              : // TLS_with_buffers_method is like |TLS_method|, but avoids all use of
     190              : // crypto/x509. All client connections created with |TLS_with_buffers_method|
     191              : // will fail unless a certificate verifier is installed with
     192              : // |SSL_set_custom_verify| or |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify|.
     193              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *TLS_with_buffers_method(void);
     194              : 
     195              : // DTLS_with_buffers_method is like |DTLS_method|, but avoids all use of
     196              : // crypto/x509.
     197              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *DTLS_with_buffers_method(void);
     198              : 
     199              : // SSL_CTX_new returns a newly-allocated |SSL_CTX| with default settings or NULL
     200              : // on error.
     201              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CTX *SSL_CTX_new(const SSL_METHOD *method);
     202              : 
     203              : // SSL_CTX_up_ref increments the reference count of |ctx|. It returns one.
     204              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_up_ref(SSL_CTX *ctx);
     205              : 
     206              : // SSL_CTX_free releases memory associated with |ctx|.
     207              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_free(SSL_CTX *ctx);
     208              : 
     209              : 
     210              : // SSL connections.
     211              : //
     212              : // An |SSL| object represents a single TLS or DTLS connection. Although the
     213              : // shared |SSL_CTX| is thread-safe, an |SSL| is not thread-safe and may only be
     214              : // used on one thread at a time.
     215              : 
     216              : // SSL_new returns a newly-allocated |SSL| using |ctx| or NULL on error. The new
     217              : // connection inherits settings from |ctx| at the time of creation. Settings may
     218              : // also be individually configured on the connection.
     219              : //
     220              : // On creation, an |SSL| is not configured to be either a client or server. Call
     221              : // |SSL_set_connect_state| or |SSL_set_accept_state| to set this.
     222              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL *SSL_new(SSL_CTX *ctx);
     223              : 
     224              : // SSL_free releases memory associated with |ssl|.
     225              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_free(SSL *ssl);
     226              : 
     227              : // SSL_get_SSL_CTX returns the |SSL_CTX| associated with |ssl|. If
     228              : // |SSL_set_SSL_CTX| is called, it returns the new |SSL_CTX|, not the initial
     229              : // one.
     230              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CTX *SSL_get_SSL_CTX(const SSL *ssl);
     231              : 
     232              : // SSL_set_connect_state configures |ssl| to be a client.
     233              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_connect_state(SSL *ssl);
     234              : 
     235              : // SSL_set_accept_state configures |ssl| to be a server.
     236              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_accept_state(SSL *ssl);
     237              : 
     238              : // SSL_is_server returns one if |ssl| is configured as a server and zero
     239              : // otherwise.
     240              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_is_server(const SSL *ssl);
     241              : 
     242              : // SSL_is_dtls returns one if |ssl| is a DTLS connection and zero otherwise.
     243              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_is_dtls(const SSL *ssl);
     244              : 
     245              : // SSL_set_bio configures |ssl| to read from |rbio| and write to |wbio|. |ssl|
     246              : // takes ownership of the two |BIO|s. If |rbio| and |wbio| are the same, |ssl|
     247              : // only takes ownership of one reference.
     248              : //
     249              : // In DTLS, |rbio| must be non-blocking to properly handle timeouts and
     250              : // retransmits.
     251              : //
     252              : // If |rbio| is the same as the currently configured |BIO| for reading, that
     253              : // side is left untouched and is not freed.
     254              : //
     255              : // If |wbio| is the same as the currently configured |BIO| for writing AND |ssl|
     256              : // is not currently configured to read from and write to the same |BIO|, that
     257              : // side is left untouched and is not freed. This asymmetry is present for
     258              : // historical reasons.
     259              : //
     260              : // Due to the very complex historical behavior of this function, calling this
     261              : // function if |ssl| already has |BIO|s configured is deprecated. Prefer
     262              : // |SSL_set0_rbio| and |SSL_set0_wbio| instead.
     263              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_bio(SSL *ssl, BIO *rbio, BIO *wbio);
     264              : 
     265              : // SSL_set0_rbio configures |ssl| to read from |rbio|. It takes ownership of
     266              : // |rbio|.
     267              : //
     268              : // Note that, although this function and |SSL_set0_wbio| may be called on the
     269              : // same |BIO|, each call takes a reference. Use |BIO_up_ref| to balance this.
     270              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set0_rbio(SSL *ssl, BIO *rbio);
     271              : 
     272              : // SSL_set0_wbio configures |ssl| to write to |wbio|. It takes ownership of
     273              : // |wbio|.
     274              : //
     275              : // Note that, although this function and |SSL_set0_rbio| may be called on the
     276              : // same |BIO|, each call takes a reference. Use |BIO_up_ref| to balance this.
     277              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set0_wbio(SSL *ssl, BIO *wbio);
     278              : 
     279              : // SSL_get_rbio returns the |BIO| that |ssl| reads from.
     280              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIO *SSL_get_rbio(const SSL *ssl);
     281              : 
     282              : // SSL_get_wbio returns the |BIO| that |ssl| writes to.
     283              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIO *SSL_get_wbio(const SSL *ssl);
     284              : 
     285              : // SSL_get_fd calls |SSL_get_rfd|.
     286              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_fd(const SSL *ssl);
     287              : 
     288              : // SSL_get_rfd returns the file descriptor that |ssl| is configured to read
     289              : // from. If |ssl|'s read |BIO| is not configured or doesn't wrap a file
     290              : // descriptor then it returns -1.
     291              : //
     292              : // Note: On Windows, this may return either a file descriptor or a socket (cast
     293              : // to int), depending on whether |ssl| was configured with a file descriptor or
     294              : // socket |BIO|.
     295              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_rfd(const SSL *ssl);
     296              : 
     297              : // SSL_get_wfd returns the file descriptor that |ssl| is configured to write
     298              : // to. If |ssl|'s write |BIO| is not configured or doesn't wrap a file
     299              : // descriptor then it returns -1.
     300              : //
     301              : // Note: On Windows, this may return either a file descriptor or a socket (cast
     302              : // to int), depending on whether |ssl| was configured with a file descriptor or
     303              : // socket |BIO|.
     304              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_wfd(const SSL *ssl);
     305              : 
     306              : #if !defined(OPENSSL_NO_SOCK)
     307              : // SSL_set_fd configures |ssl| to read from and write to |fd|. It returns one
     308              : // on success and zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of
     309              : // |fd|.
     310              : //
     311              : // On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
     312              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_fd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
     313              : 
     314              : // SSL_set_rfd configures |ssl| to read from |fd|. It returns one on success and
     315              : // zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of |fd|.
     316              : //
     317              : // On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
     318              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_rfd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
     319              : 
     320              : // SSL_set_wfd configures |ssl| to write to |fd|. It returns one on success and
     321              : // zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of |fd|.
     322              : //
     323              : // On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
     324              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_wfd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
     325              : #endif  // !OPENSSL_NO_SOCK
     326              : 
     327              : // SSL_do_handshake continues the current handshake. If there is none or the
     328              : // handshake has completed or False Started, it returns one. Otherwise, it
     329              : // returns <= 0. The caller should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to
     330              : // determine how to proceed.
     331              : //
     332              : // In DTLS, the caller must drive retransmissions. Whenever |SSL_get_error|
     333              : // signals |SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ|, use |DTLSv1_get_timeout| to determine the
     334              : // current timeout. If it expires before the next retry, call
     335              : // |DTLSv1_handle_timeout|. Note that DTLS handshake retransmissions use fresh
     336              : // sequence numbers, so it is not sufficient to replay packets at the transport.
     337              : //
     338              : // TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
     339              : // https://crbug.com/466303.
     340              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_do_handshake(SSL *ssl);
     341              : 
     342              : // SSL_connect configures |ssl| as a client, if unconfigured, and calls
     343              : // |SSL_do_handshake|.
     344              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_connect(SSL *ssl);
     345              : 
     346              : // SSL_accept configures |ssl| as a server, if unconfigured, and calls
     347              : // |SSL_do_handshake|.
     348              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_accept(SSL *ssl);
     349              : 
     350              : // SSL_read reads up to |num| bytes from |ssl| into |buf|. It implicitly runs
     351              : // any pending handshakes, including renegotiations when enabled. On success, it
     352              : // returns the number of bytes read. Otherwise, it returns <= 0. The caller
     353              : // should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to determine how to proceed.
     354              : //
     355              : // TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
     356              : // https://crbug.com/466303.
     357              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_read(SSL *ssl, void *buf, int num);
     358              : 
     359              : // SSL_peek behaves like |SSL_read| but does not consume any bytes returned.
     360              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_peek(SSL *ssl, void *buf, int num);
     361              : 
     362              : // SSL_pending returns the number of buffered, decrypted bytes available for
     363              : // read in |ssl|. It does not read from the transport.
     364              : //
     365              : // In DTLS, it is possible for this function to return zero while there is
     366              : // buffered, undecrypted data from the transport in |ssl|. For example,
     367              : // |SSL_read| may read a datagram with two records, decrypt the first, and leave
     368              : // the second buffered for a subsequent call to |SSL_read|. Callers that wish to
     369              : // detect this case can use |SSL_has_pending|.
     370              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_pending(const SSL *ssl);
     371              : 
     372              : // SSL_has_pending returns one if |ssl| has buffered, decrypted bytes available
     373              : // for read, or if |ssl| has buffered data from the transport that has not yet
     374              : // been decrypted. If |ssl| has neither, this function returns zero.
     375              : //
     376              : // In TLS, BoringSSL does not implement read-ahead, so this function returns one
     377              : // if and only if |SSL_pending| would return a non-zero value. In DTLS, it is
     378              : // possible for this function to return one while |SSL_pending| returns zero.
     379              : // For example, |SSL_read| may read a datagram with two records, decrypt the
     380              : // first, and leave the second buffered for a subsequent call to |SSL_read|.
     381              : //
     382              : // As a result, if this function returns one, the next call to |SSL_read| may
     383              : // still fail, read from the transport, or both. The buffered, undecrypted data
     384              : // may be invalid or incomplete.
     385              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_has_pending(const SSL *ssl);
     386              : 
     387              : // SSL_write writes up to |num| bytes from |buf| into |ssl|. It implicitly runs
     388              : // any pending handshakes, including renegotiations when enabled. On success, it
     389              : // returns the number of bytes written. Otherwise, it returns <= 0. The caller
     390              : // should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to determine how to proceed.
     391              : //
     392              : // In TLS, a non-blocking |SSL_write| differs from non-blocking |write| in that
     393              : // a failed |SSL_write| still commits to the data passed in. When retrying, the
     394              : // caller must supply the original write buffer (or a larger one containing the
     395              : // original as a prefix). By default, retries will fail if they also do not
     396              : // reuse the same |buf| pointer. This may be relaxed with
     397              : // |SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER|, but the buffer contents still must be
     398              : // unchanged.
     399              : //
     400              : // By default, in TLS, |SSL_write| will not return success until all |num| bytes
     401              : // are written. This may be relaxed with |SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE|. It
     402              : // allows |SSL_write| to complete with a partial result when only part of the
     403              : // input was written in a single record.
     404              : //
     405              : // In DTLS, neither |SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER| and
     406              : // |SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE| do anything. The caller may retry with a
     407              : // different buffer freely. A single call to |SSL_write| only ever writes a
     408              : // single record in a single packet, so |num| must be at most
     409              : // |SSL3_RT_MAX_PLAIN_LENGTH|.
     410              : //
     411              : // TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
     412              : // https://crbug.com/466303.
     413              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_write(SSL *ssl, const void *buf, int num);
     414              : 
     415              : // SSL_KEY_UPDATE_REQUESTED indicates that the peer should reply to a KeyUpdate
     416              : // message with its own, thus updating traffic secrets for both directions on
     417              : // the connection.
     418              : #define SSL_KEY_UPDATE_REQUESTED 1
     419              : 
     420              : // SSL_KEY_UPDATE_NOT_REQUESTED indicates that the peer should not reply with
     421              : // it's own KeyUpdate message.
     422              : #define SSL_KEY_UPDATE_NOT_REQUESTED 0
     423              : 
     424              : // SSL_key_update queues a TLS 1.3 KeyUpdate message to be sent on |ssl|
     425              : // if one is not already queued. The |request_type| argument must one of the
     426              : // |SSL_KEY_UPDATE_*| values. This function requires that |ssl| have completed a
     427              : // TLS >= 1.3 handshake. It returns one on success or zero on error.
     428              : //
     429              : // Note that this function does not _send_ the message itself. The next call to
     430              : // |SSL_write| will cause the message to be sent. |SSL_write| may be called with
     431              : // a zero length to flush a KeyUpdate message when no application data is
     432              : // pending.
     433              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_key_update(SSL *ssl, int request_type);
     434              : 
     435              : // SSL_shutdown shuts down |ssl|. It runs in two stages. First, it sends
     436              : // close_notify and returns zero or one on success or -1 on failure. Zero
     437              : // indicates that close_notify was sent, but not received, and one additionally
     438              : // indicates that the peer's close_notify had already been received.
     439              : //
     440              : // To then wait for the peer's close_notify, run |SSL_shutdown| to completion a
     441              : // second time. This returns 1 on success and -1 on failure. Application data
     442              : // is considered a fatal error at this point. To process or discard it, read
     443              : // until close_notify with |SSL_read| instead.
     444              : //
     445              : // In both cases, on failure, pass the return value into |SSL_get_error| to
     446              : // determine how to proceed.
     447              : //
     448              : // Most callers should stop at the first stage. Reading for close_notify is
     449              : // primarily used for uncommon protocols where the underlying transport is
     450              : // reused after TLS completes. Additionally, DTLS uses an unordered transport
     451              : // and is unordered, so the second stage is a no-op in DTLS.
     452              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_shutdown(SSL *ssl);
     453              : 
     454              : // SSL_CTX_set_quiet_shutdown sets quiet shutdown on |ctx| to |mode|. If
     455              : // enabled, |SSL_shutdown| will not send a close_notify alert or wait for one
     456              : // from the peer. It will instead synchronously return one.
     457              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_quiet_shutdown(SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode);
     458              : 
     459              : // SSL_CTX_get_quiet_shutdown returns whether quiet shutdown is enabled for
     460              : // |ctx|.

     462              : 
     463              : // SSL_set_quiet_shutdown sets quiet shutdown on |ssl| to |mode|. If enabled,
     464              : // |SSL_shutdown| will not send a close_notify alert or wait for one from the
     465              : // peer. It will instead synchronously return one.
     466              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_quiet_shutdown(SSL *ssl, int mode);
     467              :

     469              : // |ssl|.

     472              : // SSL_get_error returns a |SSL_ERROR_*| value for the most recent operation on
     473              : // |ssl|. It should be called after an operation failed to determine whether the
     474              : // error was fatal and, if not, when to retry.
     475              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_error(const SSL *ssl, int ret_code);
     476              : 
     477              : // SSL_ERROR_NONE indicates the operation succeeded.
     478              : #define SSL_ERROR_NONE 0
     479              :

     481              : // may inspect the error queue (see |ERR_get_error|) for more information.

     485              : // the transport. The caller may retry the operation when the transport is ready

     610              : // DTLSv1_get_timeout queries the next DTLS handshake timeout. If there is a
     611              : // timeout in progress, it sets |*out| to the time remaining and returns one.
     612              : // Otherwise, it returns zero.
     613              : //
     614              : // When the timeout expires, call |DTLSv1_handle_timeout| to handle the
     615              : // retransmit behavior.
     616              : //
     617              : // NOTE: This function must be queried again whenever the handshake state
     618              : // machine changes, including when |DTLSv1_handle_timeout| is called.
     619              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int DTLSv1_get_timeout(const SSL *ssl, struct timeval *out);
     620              : 
     621              : // DTLSv1_handle_timeout is called when a DTLS handshake timeout expires. If no
     622              : // timeout had expired, it returns 0. Otherwise, it retransmits the previous
     623              : // flight of handshake messages and returns 1. If too many timeouts had expired
     624              : // without progress or an error occurs, it returns -1.
     625              : //
     626              : // The caller's external timer should be compatible with the one |ssl| queries
     627              : // within some fudge factor. Otherwise, the call will be a no-op, but
     628              : // |DTLSv1_get_timeout| will return an updated timeout.
     629              : //
     630              : // If the function returns -1, checking if |SSL_get_error| returns
     631              : // |SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE| may be used to determine if the retransmit failed due
     632              : // to a non-fatal error at the write |BIO|. However, the operation may not be
     633              : // retried until the next timeout fires.
     634              : //
     635              : // WARNING: This function breaks the usual return value convention.
     636              : //
     637              : // TODO(davidben): This |SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE| behavior is kind of bizarre.
     638              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int DTLSv1_handle_timeout(SSL *ssl);

     763              : // Modes.
     764              : //
     765              : // Modes configure API behavior.
     766              : 
     767              : // SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE, in TLS, allows |SSL_write| to complete with a
     768              : // partial result when the only part of the input was written in a single
     769              : // record. In DTLS, it does nothing.
     770              : #define SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE 0x00000001L
     771              : 
     772              : // SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER, in TLS, allows retrying an incomplete
     773              : // |SSL_write| with a different buffer. However, |SSL_write| still assumes the
     774              : // buffer contents are unchanged. This is not the default to avoid the
     775              : // misconception that non-blocking |SSL_write| behaves like non-blocking
     776              : // |write|. In DTLS, it does nothing.
     777              : #define SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER 0x00000002L
     778              : 
     779              : // SSL_MODE_NO_AUTO_CHAIN disables automatically building a certificate chain
     780              : // before sending certificates to the peer. This flag is set (and the feature
     781              : // disabled) by default.
     782              : // TODO(davidben): Remove this behavior. https://crbug.com/boringssl/42.
     783              : #define SSL_MODE_NO_AUTO_CHAIN 0x00000008L
     784              : 
     785              : // SSL_MODE_ENABLE_FALSE_START allows clients to send application data before
     786              : // receipt of ChangeCipherSpec and Finished. This mode enables full handshakes
     787              : // to 'complete' in one RTT. See RFC 7918.
     788              : //
     789              : // When False Start is enabled, |SSL_do_handshake| may succeed before the
     790              : // handshake has completely finished. |SSL_write| will function at this point,
     791              : // and |SSL_read| will transparently wait for the final handshake leg before
     792              : // returning application data. To determine if False Start occurred or when the
     793              : // handshake is completely finished, see |SSL_in_false_start|, |SSL_in_init|,
     794              : // and |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_DONE| from |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.
     795              : #define SSL_MODE_ENABLE_FALSE_START 0x00000080L
     796              : 
     797              : // SSL_MODE_CBC_RECORD_SPLITTING causes multi-byte CBC records in TLS 1.0 to be
     798              : // split in two: the first record will contain a single byte and the second will
     799              : // contain the remainder. This effectively randomises the IV and prevents BEAST
     800              : // attacks.
     801              : #define SSL_MODE_CBC_RECORD_SPLITTING 0x00000100L
     802              : 
     803              : // SSL_MODE_NO_SESSION_CREATION will cause any attempts to create a session to
     804              : // fail with SSL_R_SESSION_MAY_NOT_BE_CREATED. This can be used to enforce that
     805              : // session resumption is used for a given SSL*.
     806              : #define SSL_MODE_NO_SESSION_CREATION 0x00000200L
     807              : 
     808              : // SSL_MODE_SEND_FALLBACK_SCSV sends TLS_FALLBACK_SCSV in the ClientHello.
     809              : // To be set only by applications that reconnect with a downgraded protocol
     810              : // version; see RFC 7507 for details.
     811              : //
     812              : // DO NOT ENABLE THIS if your application attempts a normal handshake. Only use
     813              : // this in explicit fallback retries, following the guidance in RFC 7507.
     814              : #define SSL_MODE_SEND_FALLBACK_SCSV 0x00000400L
     815              : 
     816              : // SSL_CTX_set_mode enables all modes set in |mode| (which should be one or more
     817              : // of the |SSL_MODE_*| values, ORed together) in |ctx|. It returns a bitmask

     843              : 
     844              : // SSL_CTX_set0_buffer_pool sets a |CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL| that will be used to
     845              : // store certificates. This can allow multiple connections to share
     846              : // certificates and thus save memory.
     847              : //
     848              : // The SSL_CTX does not take ownership of |pool| and the caller must ensure
     849              : // that |pool| outlives |ctx| and all objects linked to it, including |SSL|,
     850              : // |X509| and |SSL_SESSION| objects. Basically, don't ever free |pool|.
     851              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set0_buffer_pool(SSL_CTX *ctx,
     852              :                                              CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL *pool);
     853              : 
     854              : 
     855              : // Credentials.
     856              : //
     857              : // TLS endpoints may present authentication during the handshake, usually using
     858              : // X.509 certificates. This is typically required for servers and optional for
     859              : // clients. BoringSSL uses the |SSL_CREDENTIAL| object to abstract between
     860              : // different kinds of credentials, as well as configure automatic selection
     861              : // between multiple credentials. This may be used to select between ECDSA and
     862              : // RSA certificates.
     863              : //
     864              : // |SSL_CTX| and |SSL| objects maintain lists of credentials in preference
     865              : // order. During the handshake, BoringSSL will select the first usable
     866              : // credential from the list. Non-credential APIs, such as
     867              : // |SSL_CTX_use_certificate|, configure a "default credential", which is
     868              : // appended to this list if configured.
     869              : //
     870              : // When selecting credentials, BoringSSL considers the credential's type, its
     871              : // cryptographic capabilities, and capabilities advertised by the peer. This
     872              : // varies between TLS versions but includes:
     873              : //
     874              : // - Whether the peer supports the leaf certificate key
     875              : // - Whether there is a common signature algorithm that is compatible with the
     876              : //   credential
     877              : // - Whether there is a common cipher suite that is compatible with the
     878              : //   credential
     879              : //
     880              : // WARNING: In TLS 1.2 and below, there is no mechanism for servers to advertise
     881              : // supported ECDSA curves to the client. BoringSSL clients will assume the
     882              : // server accepts all ECDSA curves in client certificates.
     883              : //
     884              : // By default, BoringSSL does not check the following, though we may add APIs
     885              : // in the future to enable them on a per-credential basis.
     886              : //
     887              : // - Whether the peer supports the signature algorithms in the certificate chain
     888              : // - Whether the a server certificate is compatible with the server_name
     889              : //   extension (SNI)
     890              : // - Whether the peer supports the certificate authority that issued the
     891              : //   certificate
     892              : //
     893              : // Credentials may be configured before the handshake or dynamically in the
     894              : // early callback (see |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|) and certificate
     895              : // callback (see |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb|). These callbacks allow applications to
     896              : // use BoringSSL's built-in selection logic in tandem with custom logic. For
     897              : // example, a callback could evaluate application-specific SNI rules to filter
     898              : // down to an ECDSA and RSA credential, then configure both for BoringSSL to
     899              : // select between the two.
     900              : 
     901              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_x509 returns a new, empty X.509 credential, or NULL on
     902              : // error. Callers should release the result with |SSL_CREDENTIAL_free| when
     903              : // done.
     904              : //
     905              : // Callers should configure a certificate chain and private key on the
     906              : // credential, along with other properties, then add it with
     907              : // |SSL_CTX_add1_credential|.
     908              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CREDENTIAL *SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_x509(void);
     909              : 
     910              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_up_ref increments the reference count of |cred|.
     911              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CREDENTIAL_up_ref(SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred);
     912              : 
     913              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_free decrements the reference count of |cred|. If it reaches
     914              : // zero, all data referenced by |cred| and |cred| itself are released.
     915              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CREDENTIAL_free(SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred);
     916              : 
     917              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_private_key sets |cred|'s private key to |cred|. It
     918              : // returns one on success and zero on failure.
     919              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_private_key(SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred,
     920              :                                                    EVP_PKEY *key);
     921              : 
     922              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_signing_algorithm_prefs configures |cred| to use |prefs|
     923              : // as the preference list when signing with |cred|'s private key. It returns one
     924              : // on success and zero on error. |prefs| should not include the internal-only
     925              : // value |SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_MD5_SHA1|.
     926              : //
     927              : // It is an error to call this function with delegated credentials (see
     928              : // |SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_delegated|) because delegated credentials already
     929              : // constrain the key to a single algorithm.
     930              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_signing_algorithm_prefs(
     931              :     SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred, const uint16_t *prefs, size_t num_prefs);
     932              : 
     933              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_cert_chain sets |cred|'s certificate chain, starting from
     934              : // the leaf, to |num_cert|s certificates from |certs|. It returns one on success
     935              : // and zero on error.

     937              :                                                   CRYPTO_BUFFER *const *certs,

     939              :

     941              : // |ocsp|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
     942              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_ocsp_response(SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred,
     943              :                                                      CRYPTO_BUFFER *ocsp);
     944              : 
     945              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_signed_cert_timestamp_list sets |cred|'s list of signed
     946              : // certificate timestamps |sct_list|. |sct_list| must contain one or more SCT
     947              : // structures serialised as a SignedCertificateTimestampList (see
     948              : // https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6962#section-3.3)  i.e. each SCT is prefixed
     949              : // by a big-endian, uint16 length and the concatenation of one or more such
     950              : // prefixed SCTs are themselves also prefixed by a uint16 length. It returns one
     951              : // on success and zero on error.
     952              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_signed_cert_timestamp_list(
     953              :     SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred, CRYPTO_BUFFER *sct_list);
     954              : 
     955              : // SSL_CTX_add1_credential appends |cred| to |ctx|'s credential list. It returns
     956              : // one on success and zero on error. The credential list is maintained in order
     957              : // of decreasing preference, so earlier calls are preferred over later calls.
     958              : //
     959              : // After calling this function, it is an error to modify |cred|. Doing so may
     960              : // result in inconsistent handshake behavior or race conditions.

     966              : //
     967              : // After calling this function, it is an error to modify |cred|. Doing so may
     968              : // result in inconsistent handshake behavior or race conditions.

     973              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_certs_clear(SSL *ssl);

     975              : // SSL_get0_selected_credential returns the credential in use in the current
     976              : // handshake on |ssl|. If there is current handshake on |ssl| or if the
     977              : // handshake has not progressed to this point, it returns NULL.
     978              : //
     979              : // This function is intended for use with |SSL_CREDENTIAL_get_ex_data|. It may
     980              : // be called from handshake callbacks, such as those in
     981              : // |SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD|, to trigger credential-specific behavior.

     988              :     const SSL *ssl);
     989              : 
     990              : 
     991              : // Configuring certificates and private keys.
     992              : //
     993              : // These functions configure the connection's leaf certificate, private key, and
     994              : // certificate chain. The certificate chain is ordered leaf to root (as sent on
     995              : // the wire) but does not include the leaf. Both client and server certificates
     996              : // use these functions.
     997              : //
     998              : // Prefer to configure the certificate before the private key. If configured in
     999              : // the other order, inconsistent private keys will be silently dropped, rather
    1000              : // than return an error. Additionally, overwriting a previously-configured
    1001              : // certificate and key pair only works if the certificate is configured first.
    1002              : //
    1003              : // Each of these functions configures the default credential. To select between
    1004              : // multiple certificates, see |SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_x509| and related APIs.
    1005              : 
    1006              : // SSL_CTX_use_certificate sets |ctx|'s leaf certificate to |x509|. It returns
    1007              : // one on success and zero on failure. If |ctx| has a private key which is
    1008              : // inconsistent with |x509|, the private key is silently dropped.
    1009              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_use_certificate(SSL_CTX *ctx, X509 *x509);
    1010              : 
    1011              : // SSL_use_certificate sets |ssl|'s leaf certificate to |x509|. It returns one
    1012              : // on success and zero on failure. If |ssl| has a private key which is
    1013              : // inconsistent with |x509|, the private key is silently dropped.
    1014              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_use_certificate(SSL *ssl, X509 *x509);
    1015              : 
    1016              : // SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey sets |ctx|'s private key to |pkey|. It returns one on
    1017              : // success and zero on failure. If |ctx| had a private key or
    1018              : // |SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD| previously configured, it is replaced.
    1019              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey(SSL_CTX *ctx, EVP_PKEY *pkey);
    1020              :

    1022              : // success and zero on failure. If |ssl| had a private key or

    1078              : // SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb sets a callback that is called to select a certificate.
    1079              : // The callback returns one on success, zero on internal error, and a negative
    1080              : // number on failure or to pause the handshake. If the handshake is paused,
    1081              : // |SSL_get_error| will return |SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP|.

    1085              : // request.

    1235              : // SSL_get_all_signature_algorithm_names outputs a list of possible strings

    1237              : // It writes at most |max_out| entries to |out| and returns the total number it
    1238              : // would have written, if |max_out| had been large enough. |max_out| may be
    1239              : // initially set to zero to size the output.

    1242              : // possible strings pre-declared. This list would not be suitable to set a list

    1244              : // placeholder, experimental, or deprecated values that do not apply to every

    1409              : // Custom private keys.
    1410              : 
    1411              : enum ssl_private_key_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    1412              :   ssl_private_key_success,
    1413              :   ssl_private_key_retry,
    1414              :   ssl_private_key_failure,
    1415              : };
    1416              : 
    1417              : // ssl_private_key_method_st (aka |SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD|) describes private
    1418              : // key hooks. This is used to off-load signing operations to a custom,
    1419              : // potentially asynchronous, backend. Metadata about the key such as the type
    1420              : // and size are parsed out of the certificate.
    1421              : struct ssl_private_key_method_st {
    1422              :   // sign signs the message |in| in using the specified signature algorithm. On
    1423              :   // success, it returns |ssl_private_key_success| and writes at most |max_out|
    1424              :   // bytes of signature data to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the number of bytes
    1425              :   // written. On failure, it returns |ssl_private_key_failure|. If the operation
    1426              :   // has not completed, it returns |ssl_private_key_retry|. |sign| should
    1427              :   // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
    1428              :   // operation is completed. This will result in a call to |complete|.
    1429              :   //
    1430              :   // |signature_algorithm| is one of the |SSL_SIGN_*| values, as defined in TLS
    1431              :   // 1.3. Note that, in TLS 1.2, ECDSA algorithms do not require that curve
    1432              :   // sizes match hash sizes, so the curve portion of |SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_*| values
    1433              :   // must be ignored. BoringSSL will internally handle the curve matching logic
    1434              :   // where appropriate.
    1435              :   //
    1436              :   // It is an error to call |sign| while another private key operation is in
    1437              :   // progress on |ssl|.
    1438              :   enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*sign)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len,
    1439              :                                         size_t max_out,
    1440              :                                         uint16_t signature_algorithm,
    1441              :                                         const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
    1442              : 
    1443              :   // decrypt decrypts |in_len| bytes of encrypted data from |in|. On success it
    1444              :   // returns |ssl_private_key_success|, writes at most |max_out| bytes of
    1445              :   // decrypted data to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the actual number of bytes
    1446              :   // written. On failure it returns |ssl_private_key_failure|. If the operation
    1447              :   // has not completed, it returns |ssl_private_key_retry|. The caller should
    1448              :   // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
    1449              :   // operation is completed, which will result in a call to |complete|. This
    1450              :   // function only works with RSA keys and should perform a raw RSA decryption
    1451              :   // operation with no padding.
    1452              :   //
    1453              :   // It is an error to call |decrypt| while another private key operation is in
    1454              :   // progress on |ssl|.
    1455              :   enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*decrypt)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
    1456              :                                            size_t *out_len, size_t max_out,
    1457              :                                            const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
    1458              : 
    1459              :   // complete completes a pending operation. If the operation has completed, it
    1460              :   // returns |ssl_private_key_success| and writes the result to |out| as in
    1461              :   // |sign|. Otherwise, it returns |ssl_private_key_failure| on failure and
    1462              :   // |ssl_private_key_retry| if the operation is still in progress.
    1463              :   //
    1464              :   // |complete| may be called arbitrarily many times before completion, but it
    1465              :   // is an error to call |complete| if there is no pending operation in progress
    1466              :   // on |ssl|.
    1467              :   enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*complete)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
    1468              :                                             size_t *out_len, size_t max_out);
    1469              : };
    1470              :

    1629              : // of supported features. It is in no particular order, and may contain
    1630              : // placeholder, experimental, or deprecated values that do not apply to every
    1631              : // caller. Future versions of BoringSSL may also return strings not in this
    1632              : // list, so this does not apply if, say, sending strings across services.
    1633              : OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t SSL_get_all_standard_cipher_names(const char **out,
    1634              :                                                         size_t max_out);
    1635              : 
    1636              : 
    1637              : // Cipher suite configuration.
    1638              : //
    1639              : // OpenSSL uses a mini-language to configure cipher suites. The language
    1640              : // maintains an ordered list of enabled ciphers, along with an ordered list of
    1641              : // disabled but available ciphers. Initially, all ciphers are disabled with a
    1642              : // default ordering. The cipher string is then interpreted as a sequence of
    1643              : // directives, separated by colons, each of which modifies this state.
    1644              : //
    1645              : // Most directives consist of a one character or empty opcode followed by a
    1646              : // selector which matches a subset of available ciphers.
    1647              : //
    1648              : // Available opcodes are:
    1649              : //
    1650              : // - The empty opcode enables and appends all matching disabled ciphers to the
    1651              : //   end of the enabled list. The newly appended ciphers are ordered relative to
    1652              : //   each other matching their order in the disabled list.
    1653              : //
    1654              : // - |-| disables all matching enabled ciphers and prepends them to the disabled
    1655              : //   list, with relative order from the enabled list preserved. This means the
    1656              : //   most recently disabled ciphers get highest preference relative to other
    1657              : //   disabled ciphers if re-enabled.
    1658              : //
    1659              : // - |+| moves all matching enabled ciphers to the end of the enabled list, with
    1660              : //   relative order preserved.
    1661              : //
    1662              : // - |!| deletes all matching ciphers, enabled or not, from either list. Deleted
    1663              : //   ciphers will not matched by future operations.
    1664              : //
    1665              : // A selector may be a specific cipher (using either the standard or OpenSSL
    1666              : // name for the cipher) or one or more rules separated by |+|. The final
    1667              : // selector matches the intersection of each rule. For instance, |AESGCM+aECDSA|
    1668              : // matches ECDSA-authenticated AES-GCM ciphers.
    1669              : //
    1670              : // Available cipher rules are:
    1671              : //
    1672              : // - |ALL| matches all ciphers, except for deprecated ciphers which must be
    1673              : //   named explicitly.
    1674              : //
    1675              : // - |kRSA|, |kDHE|, |kECDHE|, and |kPSK| match ciphers using plain RSA, DHE,
    1676              : //   ECDHE, and plain PSK key exchanges, respectively. Note that ECDHE_PSK is
    1677              : //   matched by |kECDHE| and not |kPSK|.
    1678              : //
    1679              : // - |aRSA|, |aECDSA|, and |aPSK| match ciphers authenticated by RSA, ECDSA, and
    1680              : //   a pre-shared key, respectively.
    1681              : //
    1682              : // - |RSA|, |DHE|, |ECDHE|, |PSK|, |ECDSA|, and |PSK| are aliases for the
    1683              : //   corresponding |k*| or |a*| cipher rule. |RSA| is an alias for |kRSA|, not
    1684              : //   |aRSA|.
    1685              : //
    1686              : // - |3DES|, |AES128|, |AES256|, |AES|, |AESGCM|, |CHACHA20| match ciphers
    1687              : //   whose bulk cipher use the corresponding encryption scheme. Note that
    1688              : //   |AES|, |AES128|, and |AES256| match both CBC and GCM ciphers.
    1689              : //
    1690              : // - |SHA1|, and its alias |SHA|, match legacy cipher suites using HMAC-SHA1.
    1691              : //
    1692              : // Deprecated cipher rules:
    1693              : //
    1694              : // - |kEDH|, |EDH|, |kEECDH|, and |EECDH| are legacy aliases for |kDHE|, |DHE|,
    1695              : //   |kECDHE|, and |ECDHE|, respectively.
    1696              : //
    1697              : // - |HIGH| is an alias for |ALL|.
    1698              : //
    1699              : // - |FIPS| is an alias for |HIGH|.
    1700              : //
    1701              : // - |SSLv3| and |TLSv1| match ciphers available in TLS 1.1 or earlier.
    1702              : //   |TLSv1_2| matches ciphers new in TLS 1.2. This is confusing and should not
    1703              : //   be used.
    1704              : //
    1705              : // Unknown rules are silently ignored by legacy APIs, and rejected by APIs with
    1706              : // "strict" in the name, which should be preferred. Cipher lists can be long
    1707              : // and it's easy to commit typos. Strict functions will also reject the use of
    1708              : // spaces, semi-colons and commas as alternative separators.
    1709              : //
    1710              : // The special |@STRENGTH| directive will sort all enabled ciphers by strength.
    1711              : //
    1712              : // The |DEFAULT| directive, when appearing at the front of the string, expands
    1713              : // to the default ordering of available ciphers.
    1714              : //
    1715              : // If configuring a server, one may also configure equal-preference groups to
    1716              : // partially respect the client's preferences when
    1717              : // |SSL_OP_CIPHER_SERVER_PREFERENCE| is enabled. Ciphers in an equal-preference
    1718              : // group have equal priority and use the client order. This may be used to
    1719              : // enforce that AEADs are preferred but select AES-GCM vs. ChaCha20-Poly1305
    1720              : // based on client preferences. An equal-preference is specified with square
    1721              : // brackets, combining multiple selectors separated by |. For example:
    1722              : //
    1723              : //   [TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256|TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256]
    1724              : //
    1725              : // Once an equal-preference group is used, future directives must be
    1726              : // opcode-less. Inside an equal-preference group, spaces are not allowed.
    1727              : //
    1728              : // TLS 1.3 ciphers do not participate in this mechanism and instead have a
    1729              : // built-in preference order. Functions to set cipher lists do not affect TLS
    1730              : // 1.3, and functions to query the cipher list do not include TLS 1.3 ciphers.
    1731              : 
    1732              : // SSL_DEFAULT_CIPHER_LIST is the default cipher suite configuration. It is
    1733              : // substituted when a cipher string starts with 'DEFAULT'.
    1734              : #define SSL_DEFAULT_CIPHER_LIST "ALL"
    1735              : 
    1736              : // SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ctx|,
    1737              : // evaluating |str| as a cipher string and returning error if |str| contains
    1738              : // anything meaningless. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
    1739              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list(SSL_CTX *ctx,
    1740              :                                                   const char *str);
    1741              : 
    1742              : // SSL_CTX_set_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ctx|, evaluating
    1743              : // |str| as a cipher string. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
    1744              : //
    1745              : // Prefer to use |SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list|. This function tolerates
    1746              : // garbage inputs, unless an empty cipher list results.
    1747              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_cipher_list(SSL_CTX *ctx, const char *str);
    1748              : 
    1749              : // SSL_set_strict_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ssl|, evaluating
    1750              : // |str| as a cipher string and returning error if |str| contains anything
    1751              : // meaningless. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
    1752              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_strict_cipher_list(SSL *ssl, const char *str);
    1753              : 
    1754              : // SSL_set_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ssl|, evaluating |str| as
    1755              : // a cipher string. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
    1756              : //
    1757              : // Prefer to use |SSL_set_strict_cipher_list|. This function tolerates garbage
    1758              : // inputs, unless an empty cipher list results.
    1759              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_cipher_list(SSL *ssl, const char *str);
    1760              : 
    1761              : // SSL_CTX_get_ciphers returns the cipher list for |ctx|, in order of
    1762              : // preference.
    1763              : OPENSSL_EXPORT STACK_OF(SSL_CIPHER) *SSL_CTX_get_ciphers(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
    1764              : 
    1765              : // SSL_CTX_cipher_in_group returns one if the |i|th cipher (see
    1766              : // |SSL_CTX_get_ciphers|) is in the same equipreference group as the one
    1767              : // following it and zero otherwise.
    1768              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_cipher_in_group(const SSL_CTX *ctx, size_t i);
    1769              : 
    1770              : // SSL_get_ciphers returns the cipher list for |ssl|, in order of preference.
    1771              : OPENSSL_EXPORT STACK_OF(SSL_CIPHER) *SSL_get_ciphers(const SSL *ssl);
    1772              : 
    1773              :

    1775              :

    1786              : // peer, but |SSL_read| will complete the handshake before accepting application

    1791              : 
    1792              : // SSL_get_peer_certificate returns the peer's leaf certificate or NULL if the

    1794              : // result to release it.
    1795              : OPENSSL_EXPORT X509 *SSL_get_peer_certificate(const SSL *ssl);

    1799              : // of certificates as sent by the peer, not the final chain built during
    1800              : // verification. The caller does not take ownership of the result.

    1825              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER) *

    1848              : // SSL_get_tls_unique writes at most |max_out| bytes of the tls-unique value
    1849              : // for |ssl| to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the number of bytes written. It
    1850              : // returns one on success or zero on error. In general |max_out| should be at
    1851              : // least 12.

    1854              : // The tls-unique value will change after a renegotiation but, since

    1897              : 
    1898              : // Sessions.
    1899              : //
    1900              : // An |SSL_SESSION| represents an SSL session that may be resumed in an
    1901              : // abbreviated handshake. It is reference-counted and immutable. Once
    1902              : // established, an |SSL_SESSION| may be shared by multiple |SSL| objects on
    1903              : // different threads and must not be modified.
    1904              : //
    1905              : // Note the TLS notion of "session" is not suitable for application-level
    1906              : // session state. It is an optional caching mechanism for the handshake. Not all
    1907              : // connections within an application-level session will reuse TLS sessions. TLS
    1908              : // sessions may be dropped by the client or ignored by the server at any time.
    1909              : 
    1910              : DECLARE_PEM_rw(SSL_SESSION, SSL_SESSION)
    1911              : 
    1912              : // SSL_SESSION_new returns a newly-allocated blank |SSL_SESSION| or NULL on
    1913              : // error. This may be useful when writing tests but should otherwise not be
    1914              : // used.
    1915              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_SESSION_new(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
    1916              : 
    1917              : // SSL_SESSION_up_ref increments the reference count of |session| and returns
    1918              : // one.
    1919              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_SESSION_up_ref(SSL_SESSION *session);
    1920              : 
    1921              : // SSL_SESSION_free decrements the reference count of |session|. If it reaches
    1922              : // zero, all data referenced by |session| and |session| itself are released.
    1923              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_SESSION_free(SSL_SESSION *session);
    1924              :

    1927              : // ownership of the buffer and must call |OPENSSL_free| when done. It returns
    1928              : // one on success and zero on error.

    2036              : // be used.

    2119              : 
    2120              : 
    2121              : // Session caching.
    2122              : //
    2123              : // Session caching allows connections to be established more efficiently based
    2124              : // on saved parameters from a previous connection, called a session (see
    2125              : // |SSL_SESSION|). The client offers a saved session, using an opaque identifier
    2126              : // from a previous connection. The server may accept the session, if it has the
    2127              : // parameters available. Otherwise, it will decline and continue with a full
    2128              : // handshake.
    2129              : //
    2130              : // This requires both the client and the server to retain session state. A
    2131              : // client does so with a stateful session cache. A server may do the same or, if
    2132              : // supported by both sides, statelessly using session tickets. For more
    2133              : // information on the latter, see the next section.
    2134              : //
    2135              : // For a server, the library implements a built-in internal session cache as an
    2136              : // in-memory hash table. Servers may also use |SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb| and
    2137              : // |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb| to implement a custom external session cache. In
    2138              : // particular, this may be used to share a session cache between multiple
    2139              : // servers in a large deployment. An external cache may be used in addition to
    2140              : // or instead of the internal one. Use |SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode| to
    2141              : // toggle the internal cache.
    2142              : //
    2143              : // For a client, the only option is an external session cache. Clients may use
    2144              : // |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb| to register a callback for when new sessions are
    2145              : // available. These may be cached and, in subsequent compatible connections,
    2146              : // configured with |SSL_set_session|.
    2147              : //
    2148              : // Note that offering or accepting a session short-circuits certificate
    2149              : // verification and most parameter negotiation. Resuming sessions across
    2150              : // different contexts may result in security failures and surprising
    2151              : // behavior. For a typical client, this means sessions for different hosts must
    2152              : // be cached under different keys. A client that connects to the same host with,
    2153              : // e.g., different cipher suite settings or client certificates should also use
    2154              : // separate session caches between those contexts. Servers should also partition
    2155              : // session caches between SNI hosts with |SSL_CTX_set_session_id_context|.
    2156              : //
    2157              : // Note also, in TLS 1.2 and earlier, offering sessions allows passive observers
    2158              : // to correlate different client connections. TLS 1.3 and later fix this,
    2159              : // provided clients use sessions at most once. Session caches are managed by the
    2160              : // caller in BoringSSL, so this must be implemented externally. See
    2161              : // |SSL_SESSION_should_be_single_use| for details.
    2162              : 
    2163              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_OFF disables all session caching.
    2164              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_OFF 0x0000
    2165              : 
    2166              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT enables session caching for a client. The internal
    2167              : // cache is never used on a client, so this only enables the callbacks.
    2168              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT 0x0001
    2169              : 
    2170              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER enables session caching for a server.
    2171              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER 0x0002
    2172              : 
    2173              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_BOTH enables session caching for both client and server.
    2174              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_BOTH (SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT | SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER)
    2175              : 
    2176              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_AUTO_CLEAR disables automatically calling
    2177              : // |SSL_CTX_flush_sessions| every 255 connections.
    2178              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_AUTO_CLEAR 0x0080
    2179              : 
    2180              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP, on a server, disables looking up a session
    2181              : // from the internal session cache.
    2182              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP 0x0100
    2183              : 
    2184              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE, on a server, disables storing sessions in
    2185              : // the internal session cache.
    2186              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE 0x0200
    2187              : 
    2188              : // SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL, on a server, disables the internal session
    2189              : // cache.
    2190              : #define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL \
    2191              :     (SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP | SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE)
    2192              : 
    2193              : // SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode sets the session cache mode bits for |ctx| to
    2194              : // |mode|. It returns the previous value.
    2195              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode(SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode);
    2196              : 
    2197              : // SSL_CTX_get_session_cache_mode returns the session cache mode bits for
    2198              : // |ctx|
    2199              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_session_cache_mode(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
    2200              : 
    2201              : // SSL_set_session, for a client, configures |ssl| to offer to resume |session|
    2202              : // in the initial handshake and returns one. The caller retains ownership of
    2203              : // |session|. Note that configuring a session assumes the authentication in the
    2204              : // session is valid. For callers that wish to revalidate the session before
    2205              : // offering, see |SSL_SESSION_get0_peer_certificates|,
    2206              : // |SSL_SESSION_get0_signed_cert_timestamp_list|, and
    2207              : // |SSL_SESSION_get0_ocsp_response|.
    2208              : //
    2209              : // It is an error to call this function after the handshake has begun.
    2210              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_session(SSL *ssl, SSL_SESSION *session);
    2211              : 
    2212              : // SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT is the default lifetime, in seconds, of a
    2213              : // session in TLS 1.2 or earlier. This is how long we are willing to use the
    2214              : // secret to encrypt traffic without fresh key material.
    2215              : #define SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT (2 * 60 * 60)
    2216              : 
    2217              : // SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_PSK_DHE_TIMEOUT is the default lifetime, in seconds, of a

    2221              : 
    2222              : // SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_AUTH_TIMEOUT is the default non-renewable lifetime, in
    2223              : // seconds, of a TLS 1.3 session. This is how long we are willing to trust the
    2224              : // signature in the initial handshake.
    2225              : #define SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_AUTH_TIMEOUT (7 * 24 * 60 * 60)
    2226              : 
    2227              : // SSL_CTX_set_timeout sets the lifetime, in seconds, of TLS 1.2 (or earlier)

    2295              : // SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb sets the callback to be called when a new session is

    2301              : // ownership (and then calls |SSL_SESSION_free| when done) and zero otherwise. A
    2302              : // consumer which places |session| into an in-memory cache will likely return
    2303              : // one, with the cache calling |SSL_SESSION_free|. A consumer which serializes
    2304              : // |session| with |SSL_SESSION_to_bytes| may not need to retain |session| and
    2305              : // will likely return zero. Returning one is equivalent to calling
    2306              : // |SSL_SESSION_up_ref| and then returning zero.
    2307              : //

    2309              : // ticket is renewed. Further, it may not be called until some time after
    2310              : // |SSL_do_handshake| or |SSL_connect| completes if False Start is enabled. Thus

    2335              : // SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb sets a callback to look up a session by ID for a

    2337              : // |SSL_SESSION| or NULL if not found. It should set |*out_copy| to zero and

    2339              : // client.

    2345              : // removed and invalidated before the SSL library calls |SSL_SESSION_up_ref|,
    2346              : // whereas the callback may synchronize internally.

    2348              : // To look up a session asynchronously, the callback may return
    2349              : // |SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr|. See the documentation for that function and
    2350              : // |SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION|.

    2353              : // the internal cache does not return a match.

    2363              : // SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr returns a magic |SSL_SESSION|* which indicates
    2364              : // that the session isn't currently unavailable. |SSL_get_error| will then
    2365              : // return |SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION| and the handshake can be retried later
    2366              : // when the lookup has completed.
    2367              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr(void);
    2368              : 
    2369              : 
    2370              : // Session tickets.
    2371              : //
    2372              : // Session tickets, from RFC 5077, allow session resumption without server-side
    2373              : // state. The server maintains a secret ticket key and sends the client opaque
    2374              : // encrypted session parameters, called a ticket. When offering the session, the
    2375              : // client sends the ticket which the server decrypts to recover session state.
    2376              : // Session tickets are enabled by default but may be disabled with
    2377              : // |SSL_OP_NO_TICKET|.
    2378              : //
    2379              : // On the client, ticket-based sessions use the same APIs as ID-based tickets.
    2380              : // Callers do not need to handle them differently.
    2381              : //
    2382              : // On the server, tickets are encrypted and authenticated with a secret key.
    2383              : // By default, an |SSL_CTX| will manage session ticket encryption keys by
    2384              : // generating them internally and rotating every 48 hours. Tickets are minted
    2385              : // and processed transparently. The following functions may be used to configure
    2386              : // a persistent key or implement more custom behavior, including key rotation
    2387              : // and sharing keys between multiple servers in a large deployment. There are
    2388              : // three levels of customisation possible:
    2389              : //
    2390              : // 1) One can simply set the keys with |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys|.
    2391              : // 2) One can configure an |EVP_CIPHER_CTX| and |HMAC_CTX| directly for
    2392              : //    encryption and authentication.
    2393              : // 3) One can configure an |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD| to have more control
    2394              : //    and the option of asynchronous decryption.
    2395              : //
    2396              : // An attacker that compromises a server's session ticket key can impersonate
    2397              : // the server and, prior to TLS 1.3, retroactively decrypt all application
    2398              : // traffic from sessions using that ticket key. Thus ticket keys must be
    2399              : // regularly rotated for forward secrecy. Note the default key is rotated
    2400              : // automatically once every 48 hours but manually configured keys are not.
    2401              : 
    2402              : // SSL_DEFAULT_TICKET_KEY_ROTATION_INTERVAL is the interval with which the
    2403              : // default session ticket encryption key is rotated, if in use. If any
    2404              : // non-default ticket encryption mechanism is configured, automatic rotation is
    2405              : // disabled.
    2406              : #define SSL_DEFAULT_TICKET_KEY_ROTATION_INTERVAL (2 * 24 * 60 * 60)
    2407              : 
    2408              : // SSL_CTX_get_tlsext_ticket_keys writes |ctx|'s session ticket key material to
    2409              : // |len| bytes of |out|. It returns one on success and zero if |len| is not
    2410              : // 48. If |out| is NULL, it returns 48 instead.
    2411              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_tlsext_ticket_keys(SSL_CTX *ctx, void *out,
    2412              :                                                   size_t len);
    2413              : 
    2414              : // SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys sets |ctx|'s session ticket key material to
    2415              : // |len| bytes of |in|. It returns one on success and zero if |len| is not
    2416              : // 48. If |in| is NULL, it returns 48 instead.
    2417              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys(SSL_CTX *ctx, const void *in,
    2418              :                                                   size_t len);
    2419              : 
    2420              : // SSL_TICKET_KEY_NAME_LEN is the length of the key name prefix of a session
    2421              : // ticket.
    2422              : #define SSL_TICKET_KEY_NAME_LEN 16
    2423              : 
    2424              : // SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_key_cb sets the ticket callback to |callback| and
    2425              : // returns one. |callback| will be called when encrypting a new ticket and when
    2426              : // decrypting a ticket from the client.
    2427              : //
    2428              : // In both modes, |ctx| and |hmac_ctx| will already have been initialized with
    2429              : // |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_init| and |HMAC_CTX_init|, respectively. |callback|
    2430              : // configures |hmac_ctx| with an HMAC digest and key, and configures |ctx|
    2431              : // for encryption or decryption, based on the mode.
    2432              : //
    2433              : // When encrypting a new ticket, |encrypt| will be one. It writes a public
    2434              : // 16-byte key name to |key_name| and a fresh IV to |iv|. The output IV length
    2435              : // must match |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_iv_length| of the cipher selected. In this mode,
    2436              : // |callback| returns 1 on success and -1 on error.
    2437              : //
    2438              : // When decrypting a ticket, |encrypt| will be zero. |key_name| will point to a
    2439              : // 16-byte key name and |iv| points to an IV. The length of the IV consumed must
    2440              : // match |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_iv_length| of the cipher selected. In this mode,
    2441              : // |callback| returns -1 to abort the handshake, 0 if decrypting the ticket
    2442              : // failed, and 1 or 2 on success. If it returns 2, the ticket will be renewed.
    2443              : // This may be used to re-key the ticket.
    2444              : //
    2445              : // WARNING: |callback| wildly breaks the usual return value convention and is
    2446              : // called in two different modes.
    2447              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_key_cb(
    2448              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*callback)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *key_name, uint8_t *iv,
    2449              :                                   EVP_CIPHER_CTX *ctx, HMAC_CTX *hmac_ctx,
    2450              :                                   int encrypt));
    2451              : 
    2452              : // ssl_ticket_aead_result_t enumerates the possible results from decrypting a
    2453              : // ticket with an |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD|.
    2454              : enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    2455              :   // ssl_ticket_aead_success indicates that the ticket was successfully
    2456              :   // decrypted.
    2457              :   ssl_ticket_aead_success,
    2458              :   // ssl_ticket_aead_retry indicates that the operation could not be
    2459              :   // immediately completed and must be reattempted, via |open|, at a later
    2460              :   // point.
    2461              :   ssl_ticket_aead_retry,
    2462              :   // ssl_ticket_aead_ignore_ticket indicates that the ticket should be ignored
    2463              :   // (i.e. is corrupt or otherwise undecryptable).
    2464              :   ssl_ticket_aead_ignore_ticket,
    2465              :   // ssl_ticket_aead_error indicates that a fatal error occured and the
    2466              :   // handshake should be terminated.
    2467              :   ssl_ticket_aead_error,
    2468              : };
    2469              : 
    2470              : // ssl_ticket_aead_method_st (aka |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD|) contains methods
    2471              : // for encrypting and decrypting session tickets.
    2472              : struct ssl_ticket_aead_method_st {
    2473              :   // max_overhead returns the maximum number of bytes of overhead that |seal|
    2474              :   // may add.
    2475              :   size_t (*max_overhead)(SSL *ssl);
    2476              : 
    2477              :   // seal encrypts and authenticates |in_len| bytes from |in|, writes, at most,
    2478              :   // |max_out_len| bytes to |out|, and puts the number of bytes written in
    2479              :   // |*out_len|. The |in| and |out| buffers may be equal but will not otherwise
    2480              :   // alias. It returns one on success or zero on error.
    2481              :   int (*seal)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out_len,
    2482              :               const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
    2483              : 
    2484              :   // open authenticates and decrypts |in_len| bytes from |in|, writes, at most,
    2485              :   // |max_out_len| bytes of plaintext to |out|, and puts the number of bytes
    2486              :   // written in |*out_len|. The |in| and |out| buffers may be equal but will
    2487              :   // not otherwise alias. See |ssl_ticket_aead_result_t| for details of the
    2488              :   // return values. In the case that a retry is indicated, the caller should
    2489              :   // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
    2490              :   // operation is completed, which will result in another call to |open|.
    2491              :   enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t (*open)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len,
    2492              :                                         size_t max_out_len, const uint8_t *in,
    2493              :                                         size_t in_len);
    2494              : };
