    2526              : 
    2527              : // Diffie-Hellman groups and ephemeral key exchanges.
    2528              : //
    2529              : // Most TLS handshakes (ECDHE cipher suites in TLS 1.2, and all supported TLS
    2530              : // 1.3 modes) incorporate an ephemeral key exchange, most commonly using
    2531              : // Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH), as described in RFC 8422. The key
    2532              : // exchange algorithm is negotiated separately from the cipher suite, using
    2533              : // NamedGroup values, which define Diffie-Hellman groups.
    2534              : //
    2535              : // Historically, these values were known as "curves", in reference to ECDH, and
    2536              : // some APIs refer to the original name. RFC 7919 renamed them to "groups" in
    2537              : // reference to Diffie-Hellman in general. These values are also used to select
    2538              : // experimental post-quantum KEMs. Though not Diffie-Hellman groups, KEMs can
    2539              : // fill a similar role in TLS, so they use the same codepoints.
    2540              : //
    2541              : // In TLS 1.2, the ECDH values also negotiate elliptic curves used in ECDSA. In
    2542              : // TLS 1.3 and later, ECDSA curves are part of the signature algorithm. See
    2543              : // |SSL_SIGN_*|.
    2544              : 
    2545              : // SSL_GROUP_* define TLS group IDs.
    2546              : #define SSL_GROUP_SECP224R1 21
    2547              : #define SSL_GROUP_SECP256R1 23
    2548              : #define SSL_GROUP_SECP384R1 24
    2549              : #define SSL_GROUP_SECP521R1 25
    2550              : #define SSL_GROUP_X25519 29
    2551              : #define SSL_GROUP_X25519_MLKEM768 0x11ec
    2552              : #define SSL_GROUP_X25519_KYBER768_DRAFT00 0x6399
    2553              : 
    2554              : // SSL_CTX_set1_group_ids sets the preferred groups for |ctx| to |group_ids|.
    2555              : // Each element of |group_ids| should be one of the |SSL_GROUP_*| constants. It
    2556              : // returns one on success and zero on failure.
    2557              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_group_ids(SSL_CTX *ctx,
    2558              :                                           const uint16_t *group_ids,
    2559              :                                           size_t num_group_ids);
    2560              : 
    2561              : // SSL_set1_group_ids sets the preferred groups for |ssl| to |group_ids|. Each

    2563              : // returns one on success and zero on failure.
    2564              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_group_ids(SSL *ssl, const uint16_t *group_ids,
    2565              :                                       size_t num_group_ids);

    2588              : 
    2589              : // The following APIs also configure Diffie-Hellman groups, but use |NID_*|

    2620              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_negotiated_group(const SSL *ssl);
    2621              : 
    2622              : 
    2623              : // Certificate verification.
    2624              : //
    2625              : // SSL may authenticate either endpoint with an X.509 certificate. Typically
    2626              : // this is used to authenticate the server to the client. These functions
    2627              : // configure certificate verification.
    2628              : //
    2629              : // WARNING: By default, certificate verification errors on a client are not
    2630              : // fatal. See |SSL_VERIFY_NONE| This may be configured with
    2631              : // |SSL_CTX_set_verify|.
    2632              : //
    2633              : // By default clients are anonymous but a server may request a certificate from
    2634              : // the client by setting |SSL_VERIFY_PEER|.
    2635              : //
    2636              : // Many of these functions use OpenSSL's legacy X.509 stack which is
    2637              : // underdocumented and deprecated, but the replacement isn't ready yet. For
    2638              : // now, consumers may use the existing stack or bypass it by performing
    2639              : // certificate verification externally. This may be done with
    2640              : // |SSL_CTX_set_cert_verify_callback| or by extracting the chain with
    2641              : // |SSL_get_peer_cert_chain| after the handshake. In the future, functions will
    2642              : // be added to use the SSL stack without dependency on any part of the legacy
    2643              : // X.509 and ASN.1 stack.
    2644              : //
    2645              : // To augment certificate verification, a client may also enable OCSP stapling
    2646              : // (RFC 6066) and Certificate Transparency (RFC 6962) extensions.
    2647              : 
    2648              : // SSL_VERIFY_NONE, on a client, verifies the server certificate but does not
    2649              : // make errors fatal. The result may be checked with |SSL_get_verify_result|. On
    2650              : // a server it does not request a client certificate. This is the default.
    2651              : #define SSL_VERIFY_NONE 0x00
    2652              : 
    2653              : // SSL_VERIFY_PEER, on a client, makes server certificate errors fatal. On a
    2654              : // server it requests a client certificate and makes errors fatal. However,
    2655              : // anonymous clients are still allowed. See
    2656              : // |SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT|.
    2657              : #define SSL_VERIFY_PEER 0x01
    2658              : 
    2659              : // SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT configures a server to reject connections if
    2660              : // the client declines to send a certificate. This flag must be used together
    2661              : // with |SSL_VERIFY_PEER|, otherwise it won't work.
    2662              : #define SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT 0x02
    2663              : 
    2664              : // SSL_VERIFY_PEER_IF_NO_OBC configures a server to request a client certificate
    2665              : // if and only if Channel ID is not negotiated.
    2666              : #define SSL_VERIFY_PEER_IF_NO_OBC 0x04
    2667              : 
    2668              : // SSL_CTX_set_verify configures certificate verification behavior. |mode| is
    2669              : // one of the |SSL_VERIFY_*| values defined above. |callback| should be NULL.
    2670              : //
    2671              : // If |callback| is non-NULL, it is called as in |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb|,
    2672              : // which is a deprecated and fragile mechanism to run the default certificate
    2673              : // verification process, but suppress individual errors in it. See
    2674              : // |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb| for details, If set, the callback may use
    2675              : // |SSL_get_ex_data_X509_STORE_CTX_idx| with |X509_STORE_CTX_get_ex_data| to
    2676              : // look up the |SSL| from |store_ctx|.
    2677              : //
    2678              : // WARNING: |callback| is not suitable for implementing custom certificate
    2679              : // check, accepting all certificates, or extracting the certificate after
    2680              : // verification. It does not replace the default process and is called multiple
    2681              : // times throughout that process. It is also very difficult to implement this
    2682              : // callback safely, without inadvertently relying on implementation details or
    2683              : // making incorrect assumptions about when the callback is called.
    2684              : //
    2685              : // Instead, use |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify| or
    2686              : // |SSL_CTX_set_cert_verify_callback| to customize certificate verification.
    2687              : // Those callbacks can inspect the peer-sent chain, call |X509_verify_cert| and
    2688              : // inspect the result, or perform other operations more straightforwardly.
    2689              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_verify(
    2690              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode, int (*callback)(int ok, X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx));
    2691              : 
    2692              : // SSL_set_verify configures certificate verification behavior. |mode| is one of
    2693              : // the |SSL_VERIFY_*| values defined above. |callback| should be NULL.
    2694              : //
    2695              : // If |callback| is non-NULL, it is called as in |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb|,
    2696              : // which is a deprecated and fragile mechanism to run the default certificate
    2697              : // verification process, but suppress individual errors in it. See
    2698              : // |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb| for details, If set, the callback may use
    2699              : // |SSL_get_ex_data_X509_STORE_CTX_idx| with |X509_STORE_CTX_get_ex_data| to
    2700              : // look up the |SSL| from |store_ctx|.
    2701              : //
    2702              : // WARNING: |callback| is not suitable for implementing custom certificate
    2703              : // check, accepting all certificates, or extracting the certificate after
    2704              : // verification. It does not replace the default process and is called multiple
    2705              : // times throughout that process. It is also very difficult to implement this
    2706              : // callback safely, without inadvertently relying on implementation details or
    2707              : // making incorrect assumptions about when the callback is called.
    2708              : //
    2709              : // Instead, use |SSL_set_custom_verify| or |SSL_set_cert_verify_callback| to
    2710              : // customize certificate verification. Those callbacks can inspect the peer-sent
    2711              : // chain, call |X509_verify_cert| and inspect the result, or perform other
    2712              : // operations more straightforwardly.
    2713              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_verify(SSL *ssl, int mode,
    2714              :                                    int (*callback)(int ok,
    2715              :                                                    X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx));

    2723              : // SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify configures certificate verification. |mode| is one

    2726              : //
    2727              : // The callback may call |SSL_get0_peer_certificates| for the certificate chain
    2728              : // to validate. The callback should return |ssl_verify_ok| if the certificate is
    2729              : // valid. If the certificate is invalid, the callback should return
    2730              : // |ssl_verify_invalid| and optionally set |*out_alert| to an alert to send to
    2731              : // the peer. Some useful alerts include |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED|,
    2732              : // |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_REVOKED|, |SSL_AD_UNKNOWN_CA|, |SSL_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE|,
    2733              : // |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN|, and |SSL_AD_INTERNAL_ERROR|. See RFC 5246
    2734              : // section 7.2.2 for their precise meanings. If unspecified,
    2735              : // |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN| will be sent by default.
    2736              : //
    2737              : // To verify a certificate asynchronously, the callback may return

    2739              : // returning |SSL_ERROR_WANT_CERTIFICATE_VERIFY|.

    3089              : // SSL_set_SSL_CTX changes |ssl|'s |SSL_CTX|. |ssl| will use the

    3105              : // Application-layer protocol negotiation.
    3106              : //
    3107              : // The ALPN extension (RFC 7301) allows negotiating different application-layer
    3108              : // protocols over a single port. This is used, for example, to negotiate
    3109              : // HTTP/2.
    3110              : 
    3111              : // SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos sets the client ALPN protocol list on |ctx| to
    3112              : // |protos|. |protos| must be in wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
    3113              : // length-prefixed strings), or the empty string to disable ALPN. It returns
    3114              : // zero on success and one on failure. Configuring a non-empty string enables
    3115              : // ALPN on a client.
    3116              : //
    3117              : // WARNING: this function is dangerous because it breaks the usual return value
    3118              : // convention.
    3119              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos(SSL_CTX *ctx, const uint8_t *protos,
    3120              :                                            size_t protos_len);
    3121              : 
    3122              : // SSL_set_alpn_protos sets the client ALPN protocol list on |ssl| to |protos|.
    3123              : // |protos| must be in wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
    3124              : // length-prefixed strings), or the empty string to disable ALPN. It returns
    3125              : // zero on success and one on failure. Configuring a non-empty string enables
    3126              : // ALPN on a client.
    3127              : //
    3128              : // WARNING: this function is dangerous because it breaks the usual return value
    3129              : // convention.
    3130              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_alpn_protos(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *protos,
    3131              :                                        size_t protos_len);
    3132              : 
    3133              : // SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb sets a callback function on |ctx| that is called
    3134              : // during ClientHello processing in order to select an ALPN protocol from the
    3135              : // client's list of offered protocols. |SSL_select_next_proto| is an optional
    3136              : // utility function which may be useful in implementing this callback.
    3137              : //
    3138              : // The callback is passed a wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
    3139              : // length-prefixed strings) ALPN protocol list in |in|. To select a protocol,
    3140              : // the callback should set |*out| and |*out_len| to the selected protocol and
    3141              : // return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| on success. It does not pass ownership of the
    3142              : // buffer, so |*out| should point to a static string, a buffer that outlives the
    3143              : // callback call, or the corresponding entry in |in|.
    3144              : //
    3145              : // If the server supports ALPN, but there are no protocols in common, the
    3146              : // callback should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL| to abort the connection
    3147              : // with a no_application_protocol alert.
    3148              : //
    3149              : // If the server does not support ALPN, it can return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK| to
    3150              : // continue the handshake without negotiating a protocol. This may be useful if
    3151              : // multiple server configurations share an |SSL_CTX|, only some of which have
    3152              : // ALPN protocols configured.
    3153              : //
    3154              : // |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_WARNING| is ignored and will be treated as
    3155              : // |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK|.
    3156              : //
    3157              : // The callback will only be called if the client supports ALPN. Callers that
    3158              : // wish to require ALPN for all clients must check |SSL_get0_alpn_selected|
    3159              : // after the handshake. In QUIC connections, this is done automatically.
    3160              : //
    3161              : // The cipher suite is selected before negotiating ALPN. The callback may use
    3162              : // |SSL_get_pending_cipher| to query the cipher suite. This may be used to
    3163              : // implement HTTP/2's cipher suite constraints.
    3164              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb(
    3165              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
    3166              :                             const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len, void *arg),
    3167              :     void *arg);
    3168              : 
    3169              : // SSL_get0_alpn_selected gets the selected ALPN protocol (if any) from |ssl|.
    3170              : // On return it sets |*out_data| to point to |*out_len| bytes of protocol name
    3171              : // (not including the leading length-prefix byte). If the server didn't respond
    3172              : // with a negotiated protocol then |*out_len| will be zero.
    3173              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_alpn_selected(const SSL *ssl,
    3174              :                                            const uint8_t **out_data,
    3175              :                                            unsigned *out_len);
    3176              : 
    3177              : // SSL_CTX_set_allow_unknown_alpn_protos configures client connections on |ctx|
    3178              : // to allow unknown ALPN protocols from the server. Otherwise, by default, the
    3179              : // client will require that the protocol be advertised in
    3180              : // |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos|.
    3181              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_allow_unknown_alpn_protos(SSL_CTX *ctx,
    3182              :                                                           int enabled);
    3183              : 
    3184              : 
    3185              : // Application-layer protocol settings
    3186              : //
    3187              : // The ALPS extension (draft-vvv-tls-alps) allows exchanging application-layer
    3188              : // settings in the TLS handshake for applications negotiated with ALPN. Note
    3189              : // that, when ALPS is negotiated, the client and server each advertise their own
    3190              : // settings, so there are functions to both configure setting to send and query
    3191              : // received settings.
    3192              : 
    3193              : // SSL_add_application_settings configures |ssl| to enable ALPS with ALPN
    3194              : // protocol |proto|, sending an ALPS value of |settings|. It returns one on
    3195              : // success and zero on error. If |proto| is negotiated via ALPN and the peer
    3196              : // supports ALPS, |settings| will be sent to the peer. The peer's ALPS value can
    3197              : // be retrieved with |SSL_get0_peer_application_settings|.
    3198              : //
    3199              : // On the client, this function should be called before the handshake, once for
    3200              : // each supported ALPN protocol which uses ALPS. |proto| must be included in the
    3201              : // client's ALPN configuration (see |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos| and
    3202              : // |SSL_set_alpn_protos|). On the server, ALPS can be preconfigured for each
    3203              : // protocol as in the client, or configuration can be deferred to the ALPN
    3204              : // callback (see |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb|), in which case only the selected
    3205              : // protocol needs to be configured.
    3206              : //
    3207              : // ALPS can be independently configured from 0-RTT, however changes in protocol
    3208              : // settings will fallback to 1-RTT to negotiate the new value, so it is
    3209              : // recommended for |settings| to be relatively stable.
    3210              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_add_application_settings(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *proto,
    3211              :                                                 size_t proto_len,
    3212              :                                                 const uint8_t *settings,
    3213              :                                                 size_t settings_len);
    3214              : 
    3215              : // SSL_get0_peer_application_settings sets |*out_data| and |*out_len| to a
    3216              : // buffer containing the peer's ALPS value, or the empty string if ALPS was not
    3217              : // negotiated. Note an empty string could also indicate the peer sent an empty
    3218              : // settings value. Use |SSL_has_application_settings| to check if ALPS was
    3219              : // negotiated. The output buffer is owned by |ssl| and is valid until the next
    3220              : // time |ssl| is modified.
    3221              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_peer_application_settings(const SSL *ssl,
    3222              :                                                        const uint8_t **out_data,
    3223              :                                                        size_t *out_len);
    3224              : 
    3225              : // SSL_has_application_settings returns one if ALPS was negotiated on this
    3226              : // connection and zero otherwise.
    3227              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_has_application_settings(const SSL *ssl);
    3228              : 
    3229              : // SSL_set_alps_use_new_codepoint configures whether to use the new ALPS
    3230              : // codepoint. By default, the old codepoint is used.
    3231              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_alps_use_new_codepoint(SSL *ssl, int use_new);

    3234              : // Certificate compression.
    3235              : //
    3236              : // Certificates in TLS 1.3 can be compressed (RFC 8879). BoringSSL supports this
    3237              : // as both a client and a server, but does not link against any specific
    3238              : // compression libraries in order to keep dependencies to a minimum. Instead,
    3239              : // hooks for compression and decompression can be installed in an |SSL_CTX| to
    3240              : // enable support.
    3241              : 
    3242              : // ssl_cert_compression_func_t is a pointer to a function that performs
    3243              : // compression. It must write the compressed representation of |in| to |out|,
    3244              : // returning one on success and zero on error. The results of compressing
    3245              : // certificates are not cached internally. Implementations may wish to implement
    3246              : // their own cache if they expect it to be useful given the certificates that
    3247              : // they serve.
    3248              : typedef int (*ssl_cert_compression_func_t)(SSL *ssl, CBB *out,
    3249              :                                            const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
    3250              : 
    3251              : // ssl_cert_decompression_func_t is a pointer to a function that performs
    3252              : // decompression. The compressed data from the peer is passed as |in| and the
    3253              : // decompressed result must be exactly |uncompressed_len| bytes long. It returns
    3254              : // one on success, in which case |*out| must be set to the result of
    3255              : // decompressing |in|, or zero on error. Setting |*out| transfers ownership,
    3256              : // i.e. |CRYPTO_BUFFER_free| will be called on |*out| at some point in the
    3257              : // future. The results of decompressions are not cached internally.
    3258              : // Implementations may wish to implement their own cache if they expect it to be
    3259              : // useful.
    3260              : typedef int (*ssl_cert_decompression_func_t)(SSL *ssl, CRYPTO_BUFFER **out,
    3261              :                                              size_t uncompressed_len,
    3262              :                                              const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
    3263              : 
    3264              : // SSL_CTX_add_cert_compression_alg registers a certificate compression
    3265              : // algorithm on |ctx| with ID |alg_id|. (The value of |alg_id| should be an IANA
    3266              : // assigned value and each can only be registered once.)
    3267              : //
    3268              : // One of the function pointers may be NULL to avoid having to implement both
    3269              : // sides of a compression algorithm if you're only going to use it in one
    3270              : // direction. In this case, the unimplemented direction acts like it was never
    3271              : // configured.
    3272              : //
    3273              : // For a server, algorithms are registered in preference order with the most
    3274              : // preferable first. It returns one on success or zero on error.
    3275              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_add_cert_compression_alg(
    3276              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, uint16_t alg_id, ssl_cert_compression_func_t compress,
    3277              :     ssl_cert_decompression_func_t decompress);

    3279              : 
    3280              : // Next protocol negotiation.
    3281              : //
    3282              : // The NPN extension (draft-agl-tls-nextprotoneg-03) is the predecessor to ALPN
    3283              : // and deprecated in favor of it.
    3284              : 
    3285              : // SSL_CTX_set_next_protos_advertised_cb sets a callback that is called when a
    3286              : // TLS server needs a list of supported protocols for Next Protocol Negotiation.
    3287              : //
    3288              : // If the callback wishes to advertise NPN to the client, it should return
    3289              : // |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| and then set |*out| and |*out_len| to describe to a
    3290              : // buffer containing a (possibly empty) list of supported protocols in wire
    3291              : // format. That is, each protocol is prefixed with a 1-byte length, then
    3292              : // concatenated. From there, the client will select a protocol, possibly one not
    3293              : // on the server's list. The caller can use |SSL_get0_next_proto_negotiated|
    3294              : // after the handshake completes to query the final protocol.
    3295              : //
    3296              : // The returned buffer must remain valid and unmodified for at least the
    3297              : // duration of the |SSL| operation (e.g. |SSL_do_handshake|) that triggered the
    3298              : // callback.
    3299              : //
    3300              : // If the caller wishes not to advertise NPN, it should return
    3301              : // |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK|. No NPN extension will be included in the ServerHello,
    3302              : // and the TLS server will behave as if it does not implement NPN.
    3303              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_next_protos_advertised_cb(
    3304              :     SSL_CTX *ctx,
    3305              :     int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out, unsigned *out_len, void *arg),
    3306              :     void *arg);
    3307              : 
    3308              : // SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb sets a callback that is called when a client
    3309              : // needs to select a protocol from the server's provided list, passed in wire
    3310              : // format in |in_len| bytes from |in|. The callback can assume that |in| is
    3311              : // syntactically valid. |SSL_select_next_proto| is an optional utility function
    3312              : // which may be useful in implementing this callback.
    3313              : //
    3314              : // On success, the callback should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| and set |*out| and
    3315              : // |*out_len| to describe a buffer containing the selected protocol, or an
    3316              : // empty buffer to select no protocol. The returned buffer may point within
    3317              : // |in|, or it may point to some other buffer that remains valid and unmodified
    3318              : // for at least the duration of the |SSL| operation (e.g. |SSL_do_handshake|)
    3319              : // that triggered the callback.
    3320              : //
    3321              : // Returning any other value indicates a fatal error and will terminate the TLS
    3322              : // connection. To proceed without selecting a protocol, the callback must return
    3323              : // |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| and set |*out| and |*out_len| to an empty buffer. (E.g.
    3324              : // NULL and zero, respectively.)
    3325              : //
    3326              : // Configuring this callback enables NPN on a client. Although the callback can
    3327              : // then decline to negotiate a protocol, merely configuring the callback causes
    3328              : // the client to offer NPN in the ClientHello. Callers thus should not configure
    3329              : // this callback in TLS client contexts that are not intended to use NPN.
    3330              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb(
    3331              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
    3332              :                             const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len, void *arg),
    3333              :     void *arg);
    3334              : 
    3335              : // SSL_get0_next_proto_negotiated sets |*out_data| and |*out_len| to point to
    3336              : // the client's requested protocol for this connection. If the client didn't
    3337              : // request any protocol, then |*out_len| is set to zero.
    3338              : //
    3339              : // Note that the client can request any protocol it chooses. The value returned
    3340              : // from this function need not be a member of the list of supported protocols
    3341              : // provided by the server.
    3342              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_next_proto_negotiated(const SSL *ssl,
    3343              :                                                    const uint8_t **out_data,
    3344              :                                                    unsigned *out_len);
    3345              : 
    3346              : // SSL_select_next_proto implements the standard protocol selection for either
    3347              : // ALPN servers or NPN clients. It is expected that this function is called from
    3348              : // the callback set by |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb| or
    3349              : // |SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb|.
    3350              : //
    3351              : // |peer| and |supported| contain the peer and locally-configured protocols,
    3352              : // respectively. This function finds the first protocol in |peer| which is also
    3353              : // in |supported|. If one was found, it sets |*out| and |*out_len| to point to
    3354              : // it and returns |OPENSSL_NPN_NEGOTIATED|. Otherwise, it returns
    3355              : // |OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP| and sets |*out| and |*out_len| to the first
    3356              : // supported protocol.
    3357              : //
    3358              : // In ALPN, the server should only select protocols among those that the client
    3359              : // offered. Thus, if this function returns |OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP|, the caller
    3360              : // should ignore |*out| and return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL| from
    3361              : // |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb|'s callback to indicate there was no match.
    3362              : //
    3363              : // In NPN, the client may either select one of the server's protocols, or an
    3364              : // "opportunistic" protocol as described in Section 6 of
    3365              : // draft-agl-tls-nextprotoneg-03. When this function returns
    3366              : // |OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP|, |*out| implicitly selects the first supported
    3367              : // protocol for use as the opportunistic protocol. The caller may use it,
    3368              : // ignore it and select a different opportunistic protocol, or ignore it and
    3369              : // select no protocol (empty string).
    3370              : //
    3371              : // |peer| and |supported| must be vectors of 8-bit, length-prefixed byte
    3372              : // strings. The length byte itself is not included in the length. A byte string
    3373              : // of length 0 is invalid. No byte string may be truncated. |supported| must be
    3374              : // non-empty; a caller that supports no ALPN/NPN protocols should skip
    3375              : // negotiating the extension, rather than calling this function. If any of these
    3376              : // preconditions do not hold, this function will return |OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP|
    3377              : // and set |*out| and |*out_len| to an empty buffer for robustness, but callers
    3378              : // are not recommended to rely on this. An empty buffer is not a valid output
    3379              : // for |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb|'s callback.
    3380              : //
    3381              : // WARNING: |*out| and |*out_len| may alias either |peer| or |supported| and may
    3382              : // not be used after one of those buffers is modified or released. Additionally,
    3383              : // this function is not const-correct for compatibility reasons. Although |*out|
    3384              : // is a non-const pointer, callers may not modify the buffer though |*out|.
    3385              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_select_next_proto(uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
    3386              :                                          const uint8_t *peer, unsigned peer_len,
    3387              :                                          const uint8_t *supported,
    3388              :                                          unsigned supported_len);
    3389              : 
    3390              : #define OPENSSL_NPN_UNSUPPORTED 0
    3391              : #define OPENSSL_NPN_NEGOTIATED 1
    3392              : #define OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP 2
    3393              :

    3474              : // Pre-shared keys.
    3475              : //
    3476              : // Connections may be configured with PSK (Pre-Shared Key) cipher suites. These
    3477              : // authenticate using out-of-band pre-shared keys rather than certificates. See
    3478              : // RFC 4279.
    3479              : //
    3480              : // This implementation uses NUL-terminated C strings for identities and identity
    3481              : // hints, so values with a NUL character are not supported. (RFC 4279 does not
    3482              : // specify the format of an identity.)
    3483              : 
    3484              : // PSK_MAX_IDENTITY_LEN is the maximum supported length of a PSK identity,
    3485              : // excluding the NUL terminator.
    3486              : #define PSK_MAX_IDENTITY_LEN 128
    3487              : 
    3488              : // PSK_MAX_PSK_LEN is the maximum supported length of a pre-shared key.
    3489              : #define PSK_MAX_PSK_LEN 256
    3490              : 
    3491              : // SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
    3492              : // negotiated on the client. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
    3493              : // suites on the client.
    3494              : //
    3495              : // The callback is passed the identity hint in |hint| or NULL if none was
    3496              : // provided. It should select a PSK identity and write the identity and the
    3497              : // corresponding PSK to |identity| and |psk|, respectively. The identity is
    3498              : // written as a NUL-terminated C string of length (excluding the NUL terminator)
    3499              : // at most |max_identity_len|. The PSK's length must be at most |max_psk_len|.
    3500              : // The callback returns the length of the PSK or 0 if no suitable identity was
    3501              : // found.
    3502              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback(
    3503              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *hint, char *identity,
    3504              :                                  unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
    3505              :                                  unsigned max_psk_len));
    3506              : 
    3507              : // SSL_set_psk_client_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
    3508              : // negotiated on the client. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
    3509              : // suites on the client. See also |SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback|.
    3510              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_psk_client_callback(
    3511              :     SSL *ssl, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *hint, char *identity,
    3512              :                              unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
    3513              :                              unsigned max_psk_len));
    3514              : 
    3515              : // SSL_CTX_set_psk_server_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
    3516              : // negotiated on the server. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
    3517              : // suites on the server.
    3518              : //
    3519              : // The callback is passed the identity in |identity|. It should write a PSK of
    3520              : // length at most |max_psk_len| to |psk| and return the number of bytes written
    3521              : // or zero if the PSK identity is unknown.
    3522              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_psk_server_callback(

    3553              : 
    3554              : // Delegated credentials.
    3555              : //
    3556              : // Delegated credentials (RFC 9345) allow a TLS 1.3 endpoint to use its
    3557              : // certificate to issue new credentials for authentication. Once issued,
    3558              : // credentials can't be revoked. In order to mitigate the damage in case the
    3559              : // credential secret key is compromised, the credential is only valid for a
    3560              : // short time (days, hours, or even minutes).
    3561              : //
    3562              : // Currently only the authenticating side, as a server, is implemented. To
    3563              : // authenticate with delegated credentials, construct an |SSL_CREDENTIAL| with
    3564              : // |SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_delegated| and add it to the credential list. See also
    3565              : // |SSL_CTX_add1_credential|. Callers may configure a mix of delegated
    3566              : // credentials and X.509 credentials on the same |SSL| or |SSL_CTX| to support a
    3567              : // range of clients.
    3568              : 
    3569              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_delegated returns a new, empty delegated credential, or
    3570              : // NULL on error. Callers should release the result with |SSL_CREDENTIAL_free|
    3571              : // when done.
    3572              : //
    3573              : // Callers should configure a delegated credential, certificate chain and
    3574              : // private key on the credential, along with other properties, then add it with
    3575              : // |SSL_CTX_add1_credential|.
    3576              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CREDENTIAL *SSL_CREDENTIAL_new_delegated(void);
    3577              : 
    3578              : // SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_delegated_credential sets |cred|'s delegated credentials
    3579              : // structure to |dc|. It returns one on success and zero on error, including if
    3580              : // |dc| is malformed. This should be a DelegatedCredential structure, signed by
    3581              : // the end-entity certificate, as described in RFC 9345.
    3582              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CREDENTIAL_set1_delegated_credential(
    3583              :     SSL_CREDENTIAL *cred, CRYPTO_BUFFER *dc);
    3584              : 
    3585              : 
    3586              : // QUIC integration.
    3587              : //
    3588              : // QUIC acts as an underlying transport for the TLS 1.3 handshake. The following
    3589              : // functions allow a QUIC implementation to serve as the underlying transport as
    3590              : // described in RFC 9001.
    3591              : //
    3592              : // When configured for QUIC, |SSL_do_handshake| will drive the handshake as
    3593              : // before, but it will not use the configured |BIO|. It will call functions on
    3594              : // |SSL_QUIC_METHOD| to configure secrets and send data. If data is needed from
    3595              : // the peer, it will return |SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ|. As the caller receives data
    3596              : // it can decrypt, it calls |SSL_provide_quic_data|. Subsequent
    3597              : // |SSL_do_handshake| calls will then consume that data and progress the
    3598              : // handshake. After the handshake is complete, the caller should continue to
    3599              : // call |SSL_provide_quic_data| for any post-handshake data, followed by
    3600              : // |SSL_process_quic_post_handshake| to process it. It is an error to call
    3601              : // |SSL_read| and |SSL_write| in QUIC.
    3602              : //
    3603              : // 0-RTT behaves similarly to |TLS_method|'s usual behavior. |SSL_do_handshake|
    3604              : // returns early as soon as the client (respectively, server) is allowed to send
    3605              : // 0-RTT (respectively, half-RTT) data. The caller should then call
    3606              : // |SSL_do_handshake| again to consume the remaining handshake messages and
    3607              : // confirm the handshake. As a client, |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED| and
    3608              : // |SSL_reset_early_data_reject| behave as usual.
    3609              : //
    3610              : // See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9001.html#section-4.1 for more details.
    3611              : //
    3612              : // To avoid DoS attacks, the QUIC implementation must limit the amount of data
    3613              : // being queued up. The implementation can call
    3614              : // |SSL_quic_max_handshake_flight_len| to get the maximum buffer length at each
    3615              : // encryption level.
    3616              : //
    3617              : // QUIC implementations must additionally configure transport parameters with
    3618              : // |SSL_set_quic_transport_params|. |SSL_get_peer_quic_transport_params| may be
    3619              : // used to query the value received from the peer. BoringSSL handles this
    3620              : // extension as an opaque byte string. The caller is responsible for serializing
    3621              : // and parsing them. See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000#section-7.4 for
    3622              : // details.
    3623              : //
    3624              : // QUIC additionally imposes restrictions on 0-RTT. In particular, the QUIC
    3625              : // transport layer requires that if a server accepts 0-RTT data, then the
    3626              : // transport parameters sent on the resumed connection must not lower any limits
    3627              : // compared to the transport parameters that the server sent on the connection
    3628              : // where the ticket for 0-RTT was issued. In effect, the server must remember
    3629              : // the transport parameters with the ticket. Application protocols running on
    3630              : // QUIC may impose similar restrictions, for example HTTP/3's restrictions on
    3631              : // SETTINGS frames.
    3632              : //
    3633              : // BoringSSL implements this check by doing a byte-for-byte comparison of an
    3634              : // opaque context passed in by the server. This context must be the same on the
    3635              : // connection where the ticket was issued and the connection where that ticket
    3636              : // is used for 0-RTT. If there is a mismatch, or the context was not set,
    3637              : // BoringSSL will reject early data (but not reject the resumption attempt).
    3638              : // This context is set via |SSL_set_quic_early_data_context| and should cover
    3639              : // both transport parameters and any application state.
    3640              : // |SSL_set_quic_early_data_context| must be called on the server with a
    3641              : // non-empty context if the server is to support 0-RTT in QUIC.
    3642              : //
    3643              : // BoringSSL does not perform any client-side checks on the transport
    3644              : // parameters received from a server that also accepted early data. It is up to
    3645              : // the caller to verify that the received transport parameters do not lower any
    3646              : // limits, and to close the QUIC connection if that is not the case. The same
    3647              : // holds for any application protocol state remembered for 0-RTT, e.g. HTTP/3
    3648              : // SETTINGS.
    3649              : 
    3650              : // ssl_encryption_level_t represents an encryption level in TLS 1.3. Values in
    3651              : // this enum match the first 4 epochs used in DTLS 1.3 (section 6.1).
    3652              : enum ssl_encryption_level_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    3653              :   ssl_encryption_initial = 0,
    3654              :   ssl_encryption_early_data = 1,
    3655              :   ssl_encryption_handshake = 2,
    3656              :   ssl_encryption_application = 3,
    3657              : };
    3658              : 
    3659              : // ssl_quic_method_st (aka |SSL_QUIC_METHOD|) describes custom QUIC hooks.
    3660              : struct ssl_quic_method_st {
    3661              :   // set_read_secret configures the read secret and cipher suite for the given
    3662              :   // encryption level. It returns one on success and zero to terminate the
    3663              :   // handshake with an error. It will be called at most once per encryption
    3664              :   // level.
    3665              :   //
    3666              :   // BoringSSL will not release read keys before QUIC may use them. Once a level
    3667              :   // has been initialized, QUIC may begin processing data from it. Handshake
    3668              :   // data should be passed to |SSL_provide_quic_data| and application data (if
    3669              :   // |level| is |ssl_encryption_early_data| or |ssl_encryption_application|) may
    3670              :   // be processed according to the rules of the QUIC protocol.
    3671              :   //
    3672              :   // QUIC ACKs packets at the same encryption level they were received at,
    3673              :   // except that client |ssl_encryption_early_data| (0-RTT) packets trigger
    3674              :   // server |ssl_encryption_application| (1-RTT) ACKs. BoringSSL will always
    3675              :   // install ACK-writing keys with |set_write_secret| before the packet-reading
    3676              :   // keys with |set_read_secret|. This ensures the caller can always ACK any
    3677              :   // packet it decrypts. Note this means the server installs 1-RTT write keys
    3678              :   // before 0-RTT read keys.
    3679              :   //
    3680              :   // The converse is not true. An encryption level may be configured with write
    3681              :   // secrets a roundtrip before the corresponding secrets for reading ACKs is
    3682              :   // available.
    3683              :   int (*set_read_secret)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
    3684              :                          const SSL_CIPHER *cipher, const uint8_t *secret,
    3685              :                          size_t secret_len);
    3686              :   // set_write_secret behaves like |set_read_secret| but configures the write
    3687              :   // secret and cipher suite for the given encryption level. It will be called
    3688              :   // at most once per encryption level.
    3689              :   //
    3690              :   // BoringSSL will not release write keys before QUIC may use them. If |level|
    3691              :   // is |ssl_encryption_early_data| or |ssl_encryption_application|, QUIC may
    3692              :   // begin sending application data at |level|. However, note that BoringSSL
    3693              :   // configures server |ssl_encryption_application| write keys before the client
    3694              :   // Finished. This allows QUIC to send half-RTT data, but the handshake is not
    3695              :   // confirmed at this point and, if requesting client certificates, the client
    3696              :   // is not yet authenticated.
    3697              :   //
    3698              :   // See |set_read_secret| for additional invariants between packets and their
    3699              :   // ACKs.
    3700              :   //
    3701              :   // Note that, on 0-RTT reject, the |ssl_encryption_early_data| write secret
    3702              :   // may use a different cipher suite from the other keys.
    3703              :   int (*set_write_secret)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
    3704              :                           const SSL_CIPHER *cipher, const uint8_t *secret,
    3705              :                           size_t secret_len);
    3706              :   // add_handshake_data adds handshake data to the current flight at the given
    3707              :   // encryption level. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3708              :   //
    3709              :   // BoringSSL will pack data from a single encryption level together, but a
    3710              :   // single handshake flight may include multiple encryption levels. Callers
    3711              :   // should defer writing data to the network until |flush_flight| to better
    3712              :   // pack QUIC packets into transport datagrams.
    3713              :   //
    3714              :   // If |level| is not |ssl_encryption_initial|, this function will not be
    3715              :   // called before |level| is initialized with |set_write_secret|.
    3716              :   int (*add_handshake_data)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
    3717              :                             const uint8_t *data, size_t len);
    3718              :   // flush_flight is called when the current flight is complete and should be
    3719              :   // written to the transport. Note a flight may contain data at several
    3720              :   // encryption levels. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3721              :   int (*flush_flight)(SSL *ssl);
    3722              :   // send_alert sends a fatal alert at the specified encryption level. It
    3723              :   // returns one on success and zero on error.
    3724              :   //
    3725              :   // If |level| is not |ssl_encryption_initial|, this function will not be
    3726              :   // called before |level| is initialized with |set_write_secret|.
    3727              :   int (*send_alert)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level, uint8_t alert);
    3728              : };
    3729              : 
    3730              : // SSL_quic_max_handshake_flight_len returns returns the maximum number of bytes
    3731              : // that may be received at the given encryption level. This function should be
    3732              : // used to limit buffering in the QUIC implementation.
    3733              : //
    3734              : // See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9000#section-7.5
    3735              : OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t SSL_quic_max_handshake_flight_len(
    3736              :     const SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level);
    3737              : 
    3738              : // SSL_quic_read_level returns the current read encryption level.
    3739              : //
    3740              : // TODO(davidben): Is it still necessary to expose this function to callers?
    3741              : // QUICHE does not use it.
    3742              : OPENSSL_EXPORT enum ssl_encryption_level_t SSL_quic_read_level(const SSL *ssl);
    3743              : 
    3744              : // SSL_quic_write_level returns the current write encryption level.
    3745              : //
    3746              : // TODO(davidben): Is it still necessary to expose this function to callers?
    3747              : // QUICHE does not use it.
    3748              : OPENSSL_EXPORT enum ssl_encryption_level_t SSL_quic_write_level(const SSL *ssl);
    3749              : 
    3750              : // SSL_provide_quic_data provides data from QUIC at a particular encryption
    3751              : // level |level|. It returns one on success and zero on error. Note this
    3752              : // function will return zero if the handshake is not expecting data from |level|
    3753              : // at this time. The QUIC implementation should then close the connection with
    3754              : // an error.
    3755              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_provide_quic_data(SSL *ssl,
    3756              :                                          enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
    3757              :                                          const uint8_t *data, size_t len);
    3758              : 
    3759              : 
    3760              : // SSL_process_quic_post_handshake processes any data that QUIC has provided
    3761              : // after the handshake has completed. This includes NewSessionTicket messages
    3762              : // sent by the server. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3763              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_process_quic_post_handshake(SSL *ssl);
    3764              : 
    3765              : // SSL_CTX_set_quic_method configures the QUIC hooks. This should only be
    3766              : // configured with a minimum version of TLS 1.3. |quic_method| must remain valid
    3767              : // for the lifetime of |ctx|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3768              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_quic_method(SSL_CTX *ctx,
    3769              :                                            const SSL_QUIC_METHOD *quic_method);
    3770              : 
    3771              : // SSL_set_quic_method configures the QUIC hooks. This should only be
    3772              : // configured with a minimum version of TLS 1.3. |quic_method| must remain valid
    3773              : // for the lifetime of |ssl|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3774              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_quic_method(SSL *ssl,
    3775              :                                        const SSL_QUIC_METHOD *quic_method);
    3776              : 
    3777              : // SSL_set_quic_transport_params configures |ssl| to send |params| (of length
    3778              : // |params_len|) in the quic_transport_parameters extension in either the
    3779              : // ClientHello or EncryptedExtensions handshake message. It is an error to set
    3780              : // transport parameters if |ssl| is not configured for QUIC. The buffer pointed
    3781              : // to by |params| only need be valid for the duration of the call to this
    3782              : // function. This function returns 1 on success and 0 on failure.
    3783              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_quic_transport_params(SSL *ssl,
    3784              :                                                  const uint8_t *params,
    3785              :                                                  size_t params_len);
    3786              : 
    3787              : // SSL_get_peer_quic_transport_params provides the caller with the value of the
    3788              : // quic_transport_parameters extension sent by the peer. A pointer to the buffer
    3789              : // containing the TransportParameters will be put in |*out_params|, and its
    3790              : // length in |*params_len|. This buffer will be valid for the lifetime of the
    3791              : // |SSL|. If no params were received from the peer, |*out_params_len| will be 0.
    3792              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get_peer_quic_transport_params(
    3793              :     const SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out_params, size_t *out_params_len);
    3794              : 
    3795              : // SSL_set_quic_use_legacy_codepoint configures whether to use the legacy QUIC
    3796              : // extension codepoint 0xffa5 as opposed to the official value 57. Call with
    3797              : // |use_legacy| set to 1 to use 0xffa5 and call with 0 to use 57. By default,
    3798              : // the standard code point is used.
    3799              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_quic_use_legacy_codepoint(SSL *ssl, int use_legacy);
    3800              : 
    3801              : // SSL_set_quic_early_data_context configures a context string in QUIC servers
    3802              : // for accepting early data. If a resumption connection offers early data, the
    3803              : // server will check if the value matches that of the connection which minted
    3804              : // the ticket. If not, resumption still succeeds but early data is rejected.
    3805              : // This should include all QUIC Transport Parameters except ones specified that
    3806              : // the client MUST NOT remember. This should also include any application
    3807              : // protocol-specific state. For HTTP/3, this should be the serialized server
    3808              : // SETTINGS frame and the QUIC Transport Parameters (except the stateless reset
    3809              : // token).
    3810              : //
    3811              : // This function may be called before |SSL_do_handshake| or during server
    3812              : // certificate selection. It returns 1 on success and 0 on failure.
    3813              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_quic_early_data_context(SSL *ssl,
    3814              :                                                    const uint8_t *context,
    3815              :                                                    size_t context_len);
    3816              : 
    3817              : 
    3818              : // Early data.
    3819              : //
    3820              : // WARNING: 0-RTT support in BoringSSL is currently experimental and not fully
    3821              : // implemented. It may cause interoperability or security failures when used.
    3822              : //
    3823              : // Early data, or 0-RTT, is a feature in TLS 1.3 which allows clients to send
    3824              : // data on the first flight during a resumption handshake. This can save a
    3825              : // round-trip in some application protocols.
    3826              : //
    3827              : // WARNING: A 0-RTT handshake has different security properties from normal
    3828              : // handshake, so it is off by default unless opted in. In particular, early data
    3829              : // is replayable by a network attacker. Callers must account for this when
    3830              : // sending or processing data before the handshake is confirmed. See RFC 8446
    3831              : // for more information.
    3832              : //
    3833              : // As a server, if early data is accepted, |SSL_do_handshake| will complete as
    3834              : // soon as the ClientHello is processed and server flight sent. |SSL_write| may
    3835              : // be used to send half-RTT data. |SSL_read| will consume early data and
    3836              : // transition to 1-RTT data as appropriate. Prior to the transition,
    3837              : // |SSL_in_init| will report the handshake is still in progress. Callers may use
    3838              : // it or |SSL_in_early_data| to defer or reject requests as needed.
    3839              : //
    3840              : // Early data as a client is more complex. If the offered session (see
    3841              : // |SSL_set_session|) is 0-RTT-capable, the handshake will return after sending
    3842              : // the ClientHello. The predicted peer certificates and ALPN protocol will be
    3843              : // available via the usual APIs. |SSL_write| will write early data, up to the
    3844              : // session's limit. Writes past this limit and |SSL_read| will complete the
    3845              : // handshake before continuing. Callers may also call |SSL_do_handshake| again
    3846              : // to complete the handshake sooner.
    3847              : //
    3848              : // If the server accepts early data, the handshake will succeed. |SSL_read| and
    3849              : // |SSL_write| will then act as in a 1-RTT handshake. The peer certificates and
    3850              : // ALPN protocol will be as predicted and need not be re-queried.
    3851              : //
    3852              : // If the server rejects early data, |SSL_do_handshake| (and thus |SSL_read| and
    3853              : // |SSL_write|) will then fail with |SSL_get_error| returning
    3854              : // |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED|. The caller should treat this as a connection
    3855              : // error and most likely perform a high-level retry. Note the server may still
    3856              : // have processed the early data due to attacker replays.
    3857              : //
    3858              : // To then continue the handshake on the original connection, use
    3859              : // |SSL_reset_early_data_reject|. The connection will then behave as one which
    3860              : // had not yet completed the handshake. This allows a faster retry than making a
    3861              : // fresh connection. |SSL_do_handshake| will complete the full handshake,
    3862              : // possibly resulting in different peer certificates, ALPN protocol, and other
    3863              : // properties. The caller must disregard any values from before the reset and
    3864              : // query again.
    3865              : //
    3866              : // Finally, to implement the fallback described in RFC 8446 appendix D.3, retry
    3867              : // on a fresh connection without 0-RTT if the handshake fails with
    3868              : // |SSL_R_WRONG_VERSION_ON_EARLY_DATA|.
    3869              : 
    3870              : // SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled sets whether early data is allowed to be used
    3871              : // with resumptions using |ctx|.
    3872              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled(SSL_CTX *ctx, int enabled);
    3873              : 
    3874              : // SSL_set_early_data_enabled sets whether early data is allowed to be used
    3875              : // with resumptions using |ssl|. See |SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled| for more
    3876              : // information.
    3877              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_early_data_enabled(SSL *ssl, int enabled);
    3878              : 
    3879              : // SSL_in_early_data returns one if |ssl| has a pending handshake that has
    3880              : // progressed enough to send or receive early data. Clients may call |SSL_write|
    3881              : // to send early data, but |SSL_read| will complete the handshake before
    3882              : // accepting application data. Servers may call |SSL_read| to read early data
    3883              : // and |SSL_write| to send half-RTT data.
    3884              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_in_early_data(const SSL *ssl);
    3885              : 
    3886              : // SSL_SESSION_early_data_capable returns whether early data would have been
    3887              : // attempted with |session| if enabled.
    3888              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_SESSION_early_data_capable(const SSL_SESSION *session);
    3889              : 
    3890              : // SSL_SESSION_copy_without_early_data returns a copy of |session| with early
    3891              : // data disabled. If |session| already does not support early data, it returns
    3892              : // |session| with the reference count increased. The caller takes ownership of
    3893              : // the result and must release it with |SSL_SESSION_free|.
    3894              : //
    3895              : // This function may be used on the client to clear early data support from
    3896              : // existing sessions when the server rejects early data. In particular,
    3897              : // |SSL_R_WRONG_VERSION_ON_EARLY_DATA| requires a fresh connection to retry, and
    3898              : // the client would not want 0-RTT enabled for the next connection attempt.
    3899              : OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_SESSION_copy_without_early_data(
    3900              :     SSL_SESSION *session);
    3901              : 
    3902              : // SSL_early_data_accepted returns whether early data was accepted on the
    3903              : // handshake performed by |ssl|.
    3904              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_early_data_accepted(const SSL *ssl);
    3905              : 
    3906              : // SSL_reset_early_data_reject resets |ssl| after an early data reject. All
    3907              : // 0-RTT state is discarded, including any pending |SSL_write| calls. The caller
    3908              : // should treat |ssl| as a logically fresh connection, usually by driving the
    3909              : // handshake to completion using |SSL_do_handshake|.
    3910              : //
    3911              : // It is an error to call this function on an |SSL| object that is not signaling
    3912              : // |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED|.
    3913              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_reset_early_data_reject(SSL *ssl);
    3914              : 
    3915              : // SSL_get_ticket_age_skew returns the difference, in seconds, between the
    3916              : // client-sent ticket age and the server-computed value in TLS 1.3 server
    3917              : // connections which resumed a session.
    3918              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int32_t SSL_get_ticket_age_skew(const SSL *ssl);
    3919              : 
    3920              : // An ssl_early_data_reason_t describes why 0-RTT was accepted or rejected.
    3921              : // These values are persisted to logs. Entries should not be renumbered and
    3922              : // numeric values should never be reused.
    3923              : enum ssl_early_data_reason_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    3924              :   // The handshake has not progressed far enough for the 0-RTT status to be
    3925              :   // known.
    3926              :   ssl_early_data_unknown = 0,
    3927              :   // 0-RTT is disabled for this connection.
    3928              :   ssl_early_data_disabled = 1,
    3929              :   // 0-RTT was accepted.
    3930              :   ssl_early_data_accepted = 2,
    3931              :   // The negotiated protocol version does not support 0-RTT.
    3932              :   ssl_early_data_protocol_version = 3,
    3933              :   // The peer declined to offer or accept 0-RTT for an unknown reason.
    3934              :   ssl_early_data_peer_declined = 4,
    3935              :   // The client did not offer a session.
    3936              :   ssl_early_data_no_session_offered = 5,
    3937              :   // The server declined to resume the session.
    3938              :   ssl_early_data_session_not_resumed = 6,
    3939              :   // The session does not support 0-RTT.
    3940              :   ssl_early_data_unsupported_for_session = 7,
    3941              :   // The server sent a HelloRetryRequest.
    3942              :   ssl_early_data_hello_retry_request = 8,
    3943              :   // The negotiated ALPN protocol did not match the session.
    3944              :   ssl_early_data_alpn_mismatch = 9,
    3945              :   // The connection negotiated Channel ID, which is incompatible with 0-RTT.
    3946              :   ssl_early_data_channel_id = 10,
    3947              :   // Value 11 is reserved. (It has historically |ssl_early_data_token_binding|.)
    3948              :   // The client and server ticket age were too far apart.
    3949              :   ssl_early_data_ticket_age_skew = 12,
    3950              :   // QUIC parameters differ between this connection and the original.
    3951              :   ssl_early_data_quic_parameter_mismatch = 13,
    3952              :   // The application settings did not match the session.
    3953              :   ssl_early_data_alps_mismatch = 14,
    3954              :   // The value of the largest entry.
    3955              :   ssl_early_data_reason_max_value = ssl_early_data_alps_mismatch,
    3956              : };
    3957              : 
    3958              : // SSL_get_early_data_reason returns details why 0-RTT was accepted or rejected
    3959              : // on |ssl|. This is primarily useful on the server.
    3960              : OPENSSL_EXPORT enum ssl_early_data_reason_t SSL_get_early_data_reason(
    3961              :     const SSL *ssl);
    3962              : 
    3963              : // SSL_early_data_reason_string returns a string representation for |reason|, or
    3964              : // NULL if |reason| is unknown. This function may be used for logging.
    3965              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_early_data_reason_string(
    3966              :     enum ssl_early_data_reason_t reason);
    3967              : 
    3968              : 
    3969              : // Encrypted ClientHello.
    3970              : //
    3971              : // ECH is a mechanism for encrypting the entire ClientHello message in TLS 1.3.
    3972              : // This can prevent observers from seeing cleartext information about the
    3973              : // connection, such as the server_name extension.
    3974              : //
    3975              : // By default, BoringSSL will treat the server name, session ticket, and client
    3976              : // certificate as secret, but most other parameters, such as the ALPN protocol
    3977              : // list will be treated as public and sent in the cleartext ClientHello. Other
    3978              : // APIs may be added for applications with different secrecy requirements.
    3979              : //
    3980              : // ECH support in BoringSSL is still experimental and under development.
    3981              : //
    3982              : // See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-tls-esni-13.
    3983              : 
    3984              : // SSL_set_enable_ech_grease configures whether the client will send a GREASE
    3985              : // ECH extension when no supported ECHConfig is available.
    3986              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_enable_ech_grease(SSL *ssl, int enable);
    3987              : 
    3988              : // SSL_set1_ech_config_list configures |ssl| to, as a client, offer ECH with the
    3989              : // specified configuration. |ech_config_list| should contain a serialized
    3990              : // ECHConfigList structure. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    3991              : //
    3992              : // This function returns an error if the input is malformed. If the input is
    3993              : // valid but none of the ECHConfigs implement supported parameters, it will
    3994              : // return success and proceed without ECH.
    3995              : //
    3996              : // If a supported ECHConfig is found, |ssl| will encrypt the true ClientHello
    3997              : // parameters. If the server cannot decrypt it, e.g. due to a key mismatch, ECH
    3998              : // has a recovery flow. |ssl| will handshake using the cleartext parameters,
    3999              : // including a public name in the ECHConfig. If using
    4000              : // |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify|, callers should use |SSL_get0_ech_name_override|
    4001              : // to verify the certificate with the public name. If using the built-in
    4002              : // verifier, the |X509_STORE_CTX| will be configured automatically.
    4003              : //
    4004              : // If no other errors are found in this handshake, it will fail with
    4005              : // |SSL_R_ECH_REJECTED|. Since it didn't use the true parameters, the connection
    4006              : // cannot be used for application data. Instead, callers should handle this
    4007              : // error by calling |SSL_get0_ech_retry_configs| and retrying the connection
    4008              : // with updated ECH parameters. If the retry also fails with
    4009              : // |SSL_R_ECH_REJECTED|, the caller should report a connection failure.
    4010              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_ech_config_list(SSL *ssl,
    4011              :                                             const uint8_t *ech_config_list,
    4012              :                                             size_t ech_config_list_len);
    4013              : 
    4014              : // SSL_get0_ech_name_override, if |ssl| is a client and the server rejected ECH,
    4015              : // sets |*out_name| and |*out_name_len| to point to a buffer containing the ECH
    4016              : // public name. Otherwise, the buffer will be empty.
    4017              : //
    4018              : // When offering ECH as a client, this function should be called during the

    4020              : // |*out_name_len| is non-zero, the caller should verify the certificate against

    4109              : // SSL_CTX_set1_ech_keys configures |ctx| to use |keys| to decrypt encrypted
    4110              : // ClientHellos. It returns one on success, and zero on failure. If |keys| does
    4111              : // not contain any retry configs, this function will fail. Retry configs are
    4112              : // marked as such when they are added to |keys| with |SSL_ECH_KEYS_add|.
    4113              : //
    4114              : // Once |keys| has been passed to this function, it is immutable. Unlike most
    4115              : // |SSL_CTX| configuration functions, this function may be called even if |ctx|
    4116              : // already has associated connections on multiple threads. This may be used to
    4117              : // rotate keys in a long-lived server process.
    4118              : //
    4119              : // The configured ECHConfig values should also be advertised out-of-band via DNS
    4120              : // (see draft-ietf-dnsop-svcb-https). Before advertising an ECHConfig in DNS,
    4121              : // deployments should ensure all instances of the service are configured with
    4122              : // the ECHConfig and corresponding private key.
    4123              : //
    4124              : // Only the most recent fully-deployed ECHConfigs should be advertised in DNS.
    4125              : // |keys| may contain a newer set if those ECHConfigs are mid-deployment. It
    4126              : // should also contain older sets, until the DNS change has rolled out and the
    4127              : // old records have expired from caches.

    4129              : // If there is a mismatch, |SSL| objects associated with |ctx| will complete the
    4130              : // handshake using the cleartext ClientHello and send updated ECHConfig values
    4131              : // to the client. The client will then retry to recover, but with a latency
    4132              : // penalty. This recovery flow depends on the public name in the ECHConfig.
    4133              : // Before advertising an ECHConfig in DNS, deployments must ensure all instances
    4134              : // of the service can present a valid certificate for the public name.
    4135              : //
    4136              : // BoringSSL negotiates ECH before certificate selection callbacks are called,
    4137              : // including |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|. If ECH is negotiated, the
    4138              : // reported |SSL_CLIENT_HELLO| structure and |SSL_get_servername| function will
    4139              : // transparently reflect the inner ClientHello. Callers should select parameters
    4140              : // based on these values to correctly handle ECH as well as the recovery flow.
