    4296              : 
    4297              : // Handshake hints.
    4298              : //
    4299              : // WARNING: Contact the BoringSSL team before using this API. While this
    4300              : // mechanism was designed to gracefully recover from version skew and
    4301              : // configuration mismatch, splitting a single TLS server into multiple services
    4302              : // is complex.
    4303              : //
    4304              : // Some server deployments make asynchronous RPC calls in both ClientHello
    4305              : // dispatch and private key operations. In TLS handshakes where the private key
    4306              : // operation occurs in the first round-trip, this results in two consecutive RPC
    4307              : // round-trips. Handshake hints allow the RPC service to predict a signature.
    4308              : // If correctly predicted, this can skip the second RPC call.
    4309              : //
    4310              : // First, the server installs a certificate selection callback (see
    4311              : // |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|). When that is called, it performs the
    4312              : // RPC as before, but includes the ClientHello and a capabilities string from
    4313              : // |SSL_serialize_capabilities|.
    4314              : //
    4315              : // Next, the RPC service creates its own |SSL| object, applies the results of
    4316              : // certificate selection, calls |SSL_request_handshake_hints|, and runs the
    4317              : // handshake. If this successfully computes handshake hints (see
    4318              : // |SSL_serialize_handshake_hints|), the RPC server should send the hints
    4319              : // alongside any certificate selection results.
    4320              : //
    4321              : // Finally, the server calls |SSL_set_handshake_hints| and applies any
    4322              : // configuration from the RPC server. It then completes the handshake as before.
    4323              : // If the hints apply, BoringSSL will use the predicted signature and skip the
    4324              : // private key callbacks. Otherwise, BoringSSL will call private key callbacks
    4325              : // to generate a signature as before.
    4326              : //
    4327              : // Callers should synchronize configuration across the two services.
    4328              : // Configuration mismatches and some cases of version skew are not fatal, but
    4329              : // may result in the hints not applying. Additionally, some handshake flows use
    4330              : // the private key in later round-trips, such as TLS 1.3 HelloRetryRequest. In
    4331              : // those cases, BoringSSL will not predict a signature as there is no benefit.
    4332              : // Callers must allow for handshakes to complete without a predicted signature.
    4333              : 
    4334              : // SSL_serialize_capabilities writes an opaque byte string to |out| describing
    4335              : // some of |ssl|'s capabilities. It returns one on success and zero on error.
    4336              : //
    4337              : // This string is used by BoringSSL internally to reduce the impact of version
    4338              : // skew.
    4339              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_serialize_capabilities(const SSL *ssl, CBB *out);
    4340              : 
    4341              : // SSL_request_handshake_hints configures |ssl| to generate a handshake hint for
    4342              : // |client_hello|. It returns one on success and zero on error. |client_hello|
    4343              : // should contain a serialized ClientHello structure, from the |client_hello|
    4344              : // and |client_hello_len| fields of the |SSL_CLIENT_HELLO| structure.
    4345              : // |capabilities| should contain the output of |SSL_serialize_capabilities|.
    4346              : //
    4347              : // When configured, |ssl| will perform no I/O (so there is no need to configure
    4348              : // |BIO|s). For QUIC, the caller should still configure an |SSL_QUIC_METHOD|,
    4349              : // but the callbacks themselves will never be called and may be left NULL or
    4350              : // report failure. |SSL_provide_quic_data| also should not be called.
    4351              : //
    4352              : // If hint generation is successful, |SSL_do_handshake| will stop the handshake
    4353              : // early with |SSL_get_error| returning |SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY|. At
    4354              : // this point, the caller should run |SSL_serialize_handshake_hints| to extract
    4355              : // the resulting hints.
    4356              : //
    4357              : // Hint generation may fail if, e.g., |ssl| was unable to process the
    4358              : // ClientHello. Callers should then complete the certificate selection RPC and
    4359              : // continue the original handshake with no hint. It will likely fail, but this
    4360              : // reports the correct alert to the client and is more robust in case of
    4361              : // mismatch.
    4362              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_request_handshake_hints(SSL *ssl,
    4363              :                                                const uint8_t *client_hello,
    4364              :                                                size_t client_hello_len,
    4365              :                                                const uint8_t *capabilities,
    4366              :                                                size_t capabilities_len);
    4367              : 
    4368              : // SSL_serialize_handshake_hints writes an opaque byte string to |out|
    4369              : // containing the handshake hints computed by |out|. It returns one on success
    4370              : // and zero on error. This function should only be called if
    4371              : // |SSL_request_handshake_hints| was configured and the handshake terminated
    4372              : // with |SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY|.
    4373              : //
    4374              : // This string may be passed to |SSL_set_handshake_hints| on another |SSL| to
    4375              : // avoid an extra signature call.
    4376              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_serialize_handshake_hints(const SSL *ssl, CBB *out);
    4377              : 
    4378              : // SSL_set_handshake_hints configures |ssl| to use |hints| as handshake hints.
    4379              : // It returns one on success and zero on error. The handshake will then continue
    4380              : // as before, but apply predicted values from |hints| where applicable.
    4381              : //
    4382              : // Hints may contain connection and session secrets, so they must not leak and
    4383              : // must come from a source trusted to terminate the connection. However, they
    4384              : // will not change |ssl|'s configuration. The caller is responsible for
    4385              : // serializing and applying options from the RPC server as needed. This ensures

    4387              : // decisions.

    4394              : // SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback installs |cb| as the message callback for |ctx|.
    4395              : // This callback will be called when sending or receiving low-level record
    4396              : // headers, complete handshake messages, ChangeCipherSpec, and alerts.
    4397              : // |write_p| is one for outgoing messages and zero for incoming messages.
    4398              : //
    4399              : // For each record header, |cb| is called with |version| = 0 and |content_type|
    4400              : // = |SSL3_RT_HEADER|. The |len| bytes from |buf| contain the header. Note that
    4401              : // this does not include the record body. If the record is sealed, the length
    4402              : // in the header is the length of the ciphertext.
    4403              : //
    4404              : // For each handshake message, ChangeCipherSpec, and alert, |version| is the
    4405              : // protocol version and |content_type| is the corresponding record type. The
    4406              : // |len| bytes from |buf| contain the handshake message, one-byte

    4464              : 
    4465              : // SSL_set_shed_handshake_config allows some of the configuration of |ssl| to be
    4466              : // freed after its handshake completes.  Once configuration has been shed, APIs
    4467              : // that query it may fail.  "Configuration" in this context means anything that
    4468              : // was set by the caller, as distinct from information derived from the
    4469              : // handshake.  For example, |SSL_get_ciphers| queries how the |SSL| was
    4470              : // configured by the caller, and fails after configuration has been shed,
    4471              : // whereas |SSL_get_cipher| queries the result of the handshake, and is
    4472              : // unaffected by configuration shedding.
    4473              : //
    4474              : // If configuration shedding is enabled, it is an error to call |SSL_clear|.
    4475              : //
    4476              : // Note that configuration shedding as a client additionally depends on
    4477              : // renegotiation being disabled (see |SSL_set_renegotiate_mode|). If
    4478              : // renegotiation is possible, the configuration will be retained. If
    4479              : // configuration shedding is enabled and renegotiation later disabled after the
    4480              : // handshake, |SSL_set_renegotiate_mode| will shed configuration then. This may
    4481              : // be useful for clients which support renegotiation with some ALPN protocols,
    4482              : // such as HTTP/1.1, and not others, such as HTTP/2.
    4483              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_shed_handshake_config(SSL *ssl, int enable);
    4484              : 
    4485              : enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    4486              :   ssl_renegotiate_never = 0,
    4487              :   ssl_renegotiate_once,
    4488              :   ssl_renegotiate_freely,
    4489              :   ssl_renegotiate_ignore,
    4490              :   ssl_renegotiate_explicit,
    4491              : };
    4492              : 
    4493              : // SSL_set_renegotiate_mode configures how |ssl|, a client, reacts to
    4494              : // renegotiation attempts by a server. If |ssl| is a server, peer-initiated
    4495              : // renegotiations are *always* rejected and this function does nothing.
    4496              : //
    4497              : // WARNING: Renegotiation is error-prone, complicates TLS's security properties,
    4498              : // and increases its attack surface. When enabled, many common assumptions about
    4499              : // BoringSSL's behavior no longer hold, and the calling application must handle
    4500              : // more cases. Renegotiation is also incompatible with many application
    4501              : // protocols, e.g. section 9.2.1 of RFC 7540. Many functions behave in ambiguous
    4502              : // or undefined ways during a renegotiation.
    4503              : //
    4504              : // The renegotiation mode defaults to |ssl_renegotiate_never|, but may be set
    4505              : // at any point in a connection's lifetime. Set it to |ssl_renegotiate_once| to
    4506              : // allow one renegotiation, |ssl_renegotiate_freely| to allow all
    4507              : // renegotiations or |ssl_renegotiate_ignore| to ignore HelloRequest messages.
    4508              : // Note that ignoring HelloRequest messages may cause the connection to stall
    4509              : // if the server waits for the renegotiation to complete.
    4510              : //
    4511              : // If set to |ssl_renegotiate_explicit|, |SSL_read| and |SSL_peek| calls which
    4512              : // encounter a HelloRequest will pause with |SSL_ERROR_WANT_RENEGOTIATE|.
    4513              : // |SSL_write| will continue to work while paused. The caller may call
    4514              : // |SSL_renegotiate| to begin the renegotiation at a later point. This mode may
    4515              : // be used if callers wish to eagerly call |SSL_peek| without triggering a
    4516              : // renegotiation.
    4517              : //
    4518              : // If configuration shedding is enabled (see |SSL_set_shed_handshake_config|),
    4519              : // configuration is released if, at any point after the handshake, renegotiation
    4520              : // is disabled. It is not possible to switch from disabling renegotiation to
    4521              : // enabling it on a given connection. Callers that condition renegotiation on,
    4522              : // e.g., ALPN must enable renegotiation before the handshake and conditionally
    4523              : // disable it afterwards.
    4524              : //
    4525              : // When enabled, renegotiation can cause properties of |ssl|, such as the cipher
    4526              : // suite, to change during the lifetime of the connection. More over, during a
    4527              : // renegotiation, not all properties of the new handshake are available or fully
    4528              : // established. In BoringSSL, most functions, such as |SSL_get_current_cipher|,
    4529              : // report information from the most recently completed handshake, not the
    4530              : // pending one. However, renegotiation may rerun handshake callbacks, such as
    4531              : // |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb|. Such callbacks must ensure they are acting on the
    4532              : // desired versions of each property.
    4533              : //
    4534              : // BoringSSL does not reverify peer certificates on renegotiation and instead
    4535              : // requires they match between handshakes, so certificate verification callbacks
    4536              : // (see |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify|) may assume |ssl| is in the initial
    4537              : // handshake and use |SSL_get0_peer_certificates|, etc.
    4538              : //
    4539              : // There is no support in BoringSSL for initiating renegotiations as a client
    4540              : // or server.
    4541              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_renegotiate_mode(SSL *ssl,
    4542              :                                              enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t mode);
    4543              : 
    4544              : // SSL_renegotiate starts a deferred renegotiation on |ssl| if it was configured
    4545              : // with |ssl_renegotiate_explicit| and has a pending HelloRequest. It returns
    4546              : // one on success and zero on error.
    4547              : //
    4548              : // This function does not do perform any I/O. On success, a subsequent
    4549              : // |SSL_do_handshake| call will run the handshake. |SSL_write| and

    4552              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_renegotiate(SSL *ssl);

    4733              : // SSL_CTX_set_info_callback configures a callback to be run when various
    4734              : // events occur during a connection's lifetime. The |type| argument determines
    4735              : // the type of event and the meaning of the |value| argument. Callbacks must
    4736              : // ignore unexpected |type| values.
    4737              : //
    4738              : // |SSL_CB_READ_ALERT| is signaled for each alert received, warning or fatal.
    4739              : // The |value| argument is a 16-bit value where the alert level (either
    4740              : // |SSL3_AL_WARNING| or |SSL3_AL_FATAL|) is in the most-significant eight bits
    4741              : // and the alert type (one of |SSL_AD_*|) is in the least-significant eight.
    4742              : //
    4743              : // |SSL_CB_WRITE_ALERT| is signaled for each alert sent. The |value| argument
    4744              : // is constructed as with |SSL_CB_READ_ALERT|.
    4745              : //
    4746              : // |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_START| is signaled when a handshake begins. The |value|
    4747              : // argument is always one.
    4748              : //
    4749              : // |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_DONE| is signaled when a handshake completes successfully.
    4750              : // The |value| argument is always one. If a handshake False Starts, this event
    4751              : // may be used to determine when the Finished message is received.
    4752              : //
    4753              : // The following event types expose implementation details of the handshake
    4754              : // state machine. Consuming them is deprecated.
    4755              : //
    4756              : // |SSL_CB_ACCEPT_LOOP| (respectively, |SSL_CB_CONNECT_LOOP|) is signaled when
    4757              : // a server (respectively, client) handshake progresses. The |value| argument
    4758              : // is always one.
    4759              : //
    4760              : // |SSL_CB_ACCEPT_EXIT| (respectively, |SSL_CB_CONNECT_EXIT|) is signaled when
    4761              : // a server (respectively, client) handshake completes, fails, or is paused.
    4762              : // The |value| argument is one if the handshake succeeded and <= 0
    4763              : // otherwise.
    4764              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_info_callback(
    4765              :     SSL_CTX *ctx, void (*cb)(const SSL *ssl, int type, int value));
    4766              :

    4768              : // |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.

    5493              :                                                       const uint8_t **out);
    5494              : 
    5495              : // SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_cb configures the legacy OpenSSL OCSP callback and
    5496              : // returns one. Though the type signature is the same, this callback has
    5497              : // different behavior for client and server connections:
    5498              : //
    5499              : // For clients, the callback is called after certificate verification. It should
    5500              : // return one for success, zero for a bad OCSP response, and a negative number
    5501              : // for internal error. Instead, handle this as part of certificate verification.
    5502              : // (Historically, OpenSSL verified certificates just before parsing stapled OCSP
    5503              : // responses, but BoringSSL fixes this ordering. All server credentials are
    5504              : // available during verification.)
    5505              : //
    5506              : // Do not use this callback as a server. It is provided for compatibility
    5507              : // purposes only. For servers, it is called to configure server credentials. It
    5508              : // should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| on success, |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK| to
    5509              : // ignore OCSP requests, or |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL| on error. It is usually
    5510              : // used to fetch OCSP responses on demand, which is not ideal. Instead, treat
    5511              : // OCSP responses like other server credentials, such as certificates or SCT

    5594              : 
    5595              : // Compliance policy configurations
    5596              : //
    5597              : // A TLS connection has a large number of different parameters. Some are well
    5598              : // known, like cipher suites, but many are obscure and configuration functions
    5599              : // for them may not exist. These policy controls allow broad configuration
    5600              : // goals to be specified so that they can flow down to all the different
    5601              : // parameters of a TLS connection.
    5602              : 
    5603              : enum ssl_compliance_policy_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
    5604              :   // ssl_compliance_policy_none does nothing. However, since setting this
    5605              :   // doesn't undo other policies it's an error to try and set it.
    5606              :   ssl_compliance_policy_none,
    5607              : 
    5608              :   // ssl_compliance_policy_fips_202205 configures a TLS connection to use:
    5609              :   //   * TLS 1.2 or 1.3
    5610              :   //   * For TLS 1.2, only ECDHE_[RSA|ECDSA]_WITH_AES_*_GCM_SHA*.
    5611              :   //   * For TLS 1.3, only AES-GCM
    5612              :   //   * P-256 or P-384 for key agreement.
    5613              :   //   * For server signatures, only PKCS#1/PSS with SHA256/384/512, or ECDSA
    5614              :   //     with P-256 or P-384.
    5615              :   //
    5616              :   // Note: this policy can be configured even if BoringSSL has not been built in
    5617              :   // FIPS mode. Call |FIPS_mode| to check that.
    5618              :   //
    5619              :   // Note: this setting aids with compliance with NIST requirements but does not
    5620              :   // guarantee it. Careful reading of SP 800-52r2 is recommended.
    5621              :   ssl_compliance_policy_fips_202205,
    5622              : 
    5623              :   // ssl_compliance_policy_wpa3_192_202304 configures a TLS connection to use:
    5624              :   //   * TLS 1.2 or 1.3.
    5625              :   //   * For TLS 1.2, only TLS_ECDHE_[ECDSA|RSA]_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384.
    5626              :   //   * For TLS 1.3, only AES-256-GCM.
    5627              :   //   * P-384 for key agreement.
    5628              :   //   * For handshake signatures, only ECDSA with P-384 and SHA-384, or RSA
    5629              :   //     with SHA-384 or SHA-512.
    5630              :   //
    5631              :   // No limitations on the certificate chain nor leaf public key are imposed,
    5632              :   // other than by the supported signature algorithms. But WPA3's "192-bit"
    5633              :   // mode requires at least P-384 or 3072-bit along the chain. The caller must
    5634              :   // enforce this themselves on the verified chain using functions such as
    5635              :   // `X509_STORE_CTX_get0_chain`.
    5636              :   //
    5637              :   // Note that this setting is less secure than the default. The
    5638              :   // implementation risks of using a more obscure primitive like P-384
    5639              :   // dominate other considerations.
    5640              :   ssl_compliance_policy_wpa3_192_202304,
    5641              : 
    5642              :   // ssl_compliance_policy_cnsa_202407 confingures a TLS connection to use:
    5643              :   //   * For TLS 1.3, AES-256-GCM over AES-128-GCM over ChaCha20-Poly1305.
    5644              :   //
    5645              :   // I.e. it ensures that AES-GCM will be used whenever the client supports it.
    5646              :   // The cipher suite configuration mini-language can be used to similarly
    5647              :   // configure prior TLS versions if they are enabled.
    5648              :   ssl_compliance_policy_cnsa_202407,
    5649              : };
    5650              : 
    5651              : // SSL_CTX_set_compliance_policy configures various aspects of |ctx| based on
    5652              : // the given policy requirements. Subsequently calling other functions that
    5653              : // configure |ctx| may override |policy|, or may not. This should be the final
    5654              : // configuration function called in order to have defined behaviour. It's a

    5839              : 
    5840              : // *** DEPRECATED EXPERIMENT  DO NOT USE ***
    5841              : //
    5842              : // Split handshakes.
    5843              : //
    5844              : // WARNING: This mechanism is deprecated and should not be used. It is very
    5845              : // fragile and difficult to use correctly. The relationship between
    5846              : // configuration options across the two halves is ill-defined and not
    5847              : // self-consistent. Additionally, version skew across the two halves risks
    5848              : // unusual behavior and connection failure. New development should use the
    5849              : // handshake hints API. Existing deployments should migrate to handshake hints
    5850              : // to reduce the risk of service outages.
    5851              : //
    5852              : // Split handshakes allows the handshake part of a TLS connection to be
    5853              : // performed in a different process (or on a different machine) than the data
    5854              : // exchange. This only applies to servers.
    5855              : //
    5856              : // In the first part of a split handshake, an |SSL| (where the |SSL_CTX| has
    5857              : // been configured with |SSL_CTX_set_handoff_mode|) is used normally. Once the
    5858              : // ClientHello message has been received, the handshake will stop and
    5859              : // |SSL_get_error| will indicate |SSL_ERROR_HANDOFF|. At this point (and only
    5860              : // at this point), |SSL_serialize_handoff| can be called to write the handoff
    5861              : // state of the connection.
    5862              : //
    5863              : // Elsewhere, a fresh |SSL| can be used with |SSL_apply_handoff| to continue
    5864              : // the connection. The connection from the client is fed into this |SSL|, and
    5865              : // the handshake resumed. When the handshake stops again and |SSL_get_error|
    5866              : // indicates |SSL_ERROR_HANDBACK|, |SSL_serialize_handback| should be called to
    5867              : // serialize the state of the handshake again.
    5868              : //
    5869              : // Back at the first location, a fresh |SSL| can be used with
    5870              : // |SSL_apply_handback|. Then the client's connection can be processed mostly
    5871              : // as normal.
    5872              : //
    5873              : // Lastly, when a connection is in the handoff state, whether or not
    5874              : // |SSL_serialize_handoff| is called, |SSL_decline_handoff| will move it back
    5875              : // into a normal state where the connection can proceed without impact.
    5876              : //
    5877              : // WARNING: Currently only works with TLS 1.01.2.
    5878              : // WARNING: The serialisation formats are not yet stable: version skew may be
    5879              : //     fatal.
    5880              : // WARNING: The handback data contains sensitive key material and must be
    5881              : //     protected.
    5882              : // WARNING: Some calls on the final |SSL| will not work. Just as an example,
    5883              : //     calls like |SSL_get0_session_id_context| and |SSL_get_privatekey| won't
    5884              : //     work because the certificate used for handshaking isn't available.
    5885              : // WARNING: |SSL_apply_handoff| may trigger msg callback calls.
